pkg_check_modules. This is rectified by explicitly unsetting OPENCL_FOUND.

title: EinsteinToolkit: add a subdevice test

EinsteinToolkit: add a subdevice test

Adds an option "s" to the EinsteinToolkit, which makes it
create a subdevice of 2 CUs and use that instead of main
device.

Also adds a CMake test for it - EinsteinToolkit_SubDev, which
runs with POCL_AFFINITY=1 so it's quite easy to verify if
subdevices are working as expected.

title: pthread driver: use spinlocks on work queue
message:
pthread driver: use spinlocks on work queue

The wq_lock (work queue lock) in pthread driver was
used for both wake_pool cond variable (signaling when
there was new work to be done) and also to lock access
to kernel/command queues.

The problem with this approach is, with many threads
there would be high lock contention on wq_lock; the
operation would block by doing a syscall, at which
point the linux scheduler would schedule it off the
CPU. This resulted in pthread_scheduler_get_work()
often wasting ~10 ms just to take a look at two
pointers.

This commit adds a separate lock for the wake_pool
cond variable, and another spin lock for the cmd/kernel
queue variables. The spin lock should be a safe
option since it's only ever protecting simple pointer
checks.

Similarly, kernel_run_command->lock was changed to a
spinlock.

message:
Fix #289: pocl aborts with "Could not create topdir for cache"

As I've described in a comment, #289 is not a pocl issue,
but it might be better to not call abort() in this case,
because the user's program might be able to fallback (using
other OpenCL platform, or using something else entirely).
This commit changes pocl to return CL_DEVICE_NOT_FOUND (it
will still log the error).

title: pthread driver: handle user events including failures
message:
pthread driver: handle user events including failures

Turns out a conformant implementation cannot move events to
CL_SUBMITTED state if they depend on any user events. Only after
the user event is either CL_COMPLETED or failed, can we change
dependent events from CL_QUEUED to CL_SUBMITTED or failed.

This patch also removes some old code that was actually
unused for a while (command list).

message:
libclc: isnan(), isfinite(), isinf(), isnormal()

These implementations do not depend on clang builtins.

This is not strictly necessary, merely a workaround for a bug
likely in some LLVM 4 optimization pass, where it fails to
compile the conformance tests for isnan() / nan() vector size 8.
Other vector sizes and LLVM 5 work with the code which uses
builtins.

Apparently, with -O0 (or no -O option) Clang adds the
noinline attribute to each C function in kernel library,
which makes it impossible to inline later, however
trivial it might be.

title: Use the clang builtin names for intrinsics in vload_store_half_f16c.c
message:
Use the clang builtin names for intrinsics in vload_store_half_f16c.c

This way we don't need to include x86intrin.h which redefines the size_t
typedef which is also defined in pocl_types.h

This fixes the build on i686 and arm:

In file included from /builddir/build/BUILD/pocl-53ef5e89aa99b5e85ad512ff46aa8f38b36acf4f/lib/kernel/vload_store_half_f16c.c:50:
In file included from /usr/lib/clang/5.0.0/include/x86intrin.h:29:
In file included from /usr/lib/clang/5.0.0/include/immintrin.h:32:
In file included from /usr/lib/clang/5.0.0/include/xmmintrin.h:39:
In file included from /usr/lib/clang/5.0.0/include/mm_malloc.h:27:
In file included from /usr/include/stdlib.h:31:
/usr/lib/clang/5.0.0/include/stddef.h:62:23: error: typedef redefinition with different types ('unsigned int' vs 'ulong' (aka 'unsigned long'))
typedef __SIZE_TYPE__ size_t;
                      ^
/builddir/build/BUILD/pocl-53ef5e89aa99b5e85ad512ff46aa8f38b36acf4f/include/pocl_types.h:23:15: note: previous definition is here

              ^

title: Set content of CL_DEVICE_NAME and CL_DEVICE_VENDOR to meaningful values for…
message: Set content of CL_DEVICE_NAME and CL_DEVICE_VENDOR to meaningful values for __arm__ and __aarch64__ host targets

title: replace C++ comment style with C comment style in pocl_binary.c
message: replace C++ comment style with C comment style in pocl_binary.c

title: fix issue #537 (pocl_binaries are not functionnal)
message:
fix issue #537 (pocl_binaries are not functionnal)

We need to skip program.bc in a pocl_binaries when we want to have
information on kernels from the start of a pocl_binaries.
When running POCL offline, we do not need to take care of
program->binaries (even if they are present) as we do not have a
compiler available.

title: Added myself to CREDITS
message:
Added myself to CREDITS

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

title: [CUDA] NVIDIA is the GPU vendor
message: [CUDA] NVIDIA is the GPU vendor

title: [CUDA] driver can tell us if the memory is unified
message: [CUDA] driver can tell us if the memory is unified

title: [CUDA] Use texture alignment for base address align
message:
[CUDA] Use texture alignment for base address align

This matches the behavior of NVIDIA's implementation.

Signed-off-by: Giuseppe Bilotta <giuseppe.bilotta@gmail.com>

title: [CUDA] Sanitize attribute fetch
message:
[CUDA] Sanitize attribute fetch

Instead of casting the pocl device fields to int, which only works with
the correct endianness if sizeof(size_t) > sizeof(int), fetch to a
separate integer value and then assign to the correct field.

Also check the return value of all calls (together).

Signed-off-by: Giuseppe Bilotta <giuseppe.bilotta@gmail.com>

title: Added Ronan to CREDITS
message: Added Ronan to CREDITS

title: Add minimal support for pseudo SPIR 2.0 input generated by Clang 3.9
message:
Add minimal support for pseudo SPIR 2.0 input generated by Clang 3.9

This SPIR "de-facto", which is basically some SPIR 2.0 encoded in more
modern LLVM IR than 3.4 is non-conforming SPIR 2.0 but is easier to
generate by some projects with post-3.4 Clang and/or LLVM and it is
nice to be able to consume it with PoCL.

This was tested with https://github.com/triSYCL/triSYCL

title: Merge branch 'next' of https://github.com/franz/pocl
message: Merge branch 'next' of https://github.com/franz/pocl

title: Fix malloc size in tests/runtime/test_clBuildProgram.c
message: Fix malloc size in tests/runtime/test_clBuildProgram.c

title: LLVM API: replace llvm::sys::Mutex / MutexGuard with Pocl's own
message:
LLVM API: replace llvm::sys::Mutex / MutexGuard with Pocl's own

Using LLVM's Mutex classes was causing issues due to destructor
calling order. See comments in pocl_llvm_api.h for details.

title: [CUDA] Fix libdevice filename for CUDA 9+
message:
[CUDA] Fix libdevice filename for CUDA 9+

Fixes #524.

title: Fix #516 - WI-loops don't consider alignment for context arrays
message:
Fix #516 - WI-loops don't consider alignment for context arrays

This fixes a bug uncovered by optimizer vectorizing some loops.
WI-loops pass need to consider both size and alignment when creating
context arrays.

title: Fix #517 - image samplers are broken by optimization
message:
Fix #517 - image samplers are broken by optimization

For some reason DSE optimizes out the store to allocated
sampler_t. This workarounds it by marking the store volatile.

title: Fix const/pure attributes on convert* and read_image*
message:
Fix const/pure attributes on convert* and read_image*

This fixes attributes on part of pocl's kernel library
to match those in opencl-c.h

title: Fix opencl-c.h #defines colliding with pocl's
message:
Fix opencl-c.h #defines colliding with pocl's

Clang's opencl-c.h defines several constants with different values as pocl;
fixed pocl's headers.

This commit also makes pocl pick up constants from opencl-c.h when it's
available.

title: pocl_build.c: don't lock when reading bitcode
message:
pocl_build.c: don't lock when reading bitcode

Since writing bitcode is now atomic (via rename), it
shouldn't be necessary to lock while reading / parsing IR.

title: Fix signal handling to work with LLVM's signal handling.
message:
Fix signal handling to work with LLVM's signal handling.

LLVM registering its own signal handlers was causing
interesting bugs & crashes. This forces LLVM to register
its handlers before pocl registers its SIGFPE handler.

title: Remove pocl_queue_util.{h,c}
message:
Remove pocl_queue_util.{h,c}

This code has been unused for a while; also, atexit() on shared
library is only called when it's dlclose()d, so not terribly
useful as cleanup for Pocl.

title: Revert "Fix SIGFPE handling"
message:
Revert "Fix SIGFPE handling"

This reverts commit 3c2b7c0b29e4a8eda1737df549f353baca8d3593, which
was work-in-progress and was commited by mistake.

title: Split up pocl_llvm_api.cc into multiple files
message:
Split up pocl_llvm_api.cc into multiple files

File has grown too big, and compile times too. Split up into
four files: utils, metadata-, workgroup(parallel.bc)-related, and
build/link(program.bc)-related tasks.

Added pocl_llvm_api.h to connect them all (unlike pocl_llvm.h it
exports C++ code, not C).

title: Partial fix for user events
message:
Partial fix for user events

This fixes a deadlock (but does not yet make user events fully conformant)

title: Fix issue #225 - clBuildProgram doesn't call the notification callback
message:
Fix issue #225 - clBuildProgram doesn't call the notification callback

It wasn't calling it for the few initial sanity checks.

title: Fix issue #222 - Missing required double features
message:
Fix issue #222 - Missing required double features

Disables reporting floats when HOST_DEVICE_EXTENSIONS is missing
cl_khr_fp64.

title: vstore_half: fix for double arguments and rounding
message:
vstore_half: fix for double arguments and rounding

Add properly rounding float2half and double2half implementations.
Pocl now passes conformance test on halfs.

title: Fix memfence() incompatibility with LLVM's opencl headers
message: Fix memfence() incompatibility with LLVM's opencl headers

title: pocl_cache: Add an explanation of why pocl may fail to create a cache
message:
pocl_cache: Add an explanation of why pocl may fail to create a cache
top directory.

title: pocl_binary: (de)serialize also program binary_type
message: pocl_binary: (de)serialize also program binary_type

title: Do not link CL_PROGRAM_BINARY_TYPE_LIBRARY programs to pocl's kernellib,
message:
Do not link CL_PROGRAM_BINARY_TYPE_LIBRARY programs to pocl's kernellib,
only when linking the final executable.

Otherwise program which links to libraries can crash because there
will be multiple definitions for symbols.

title: CMake: mark example1-spirXX tests as fail on LLVM < 3.9
message:
CMake: mark example1-spirXX tests as fail on LLVM < 3.9

a bit more churn is necessary because cmake's WILL_FAIL test
property is bordering on useless.

title: CMake: move add_test_pocl() to cmake/
message:
CMake: move add_test_pocl() to cmake/

necessary because it will be required in examples/ too,
not only tests/.

title: examples/AMDSDK3: DeviceFission test no longer fails.
message: examples/AMDSDK3: DeviceFission test no longer fails.

title: TCE: fix tests to use printf() instead of putchar().
message:
TCE: fix tests to use printf() instead of putchar().

Since putchar() is not in kernel library, it was now
failing on the undefined symbols check during linking.

title: Fix SPIR bitcode for example1-spir32/64
message:
Fix SPIR bitcode for example1-spir32/64

Since linking kernel library now happens in pocl_llvm_build_program
stage, we expect all binaries to be fully linked. This broke SPIR
examples, so this patch updates the examples with fully linked SPIR
binaries.

The real fix would be to link the SPIR binaries at clBuildProgram,
but we need an actual SPIR kernel library first to do that (the
previously used hack of linking to host library is too fragile).

message: Fix program binary_type handling

message: fix clCompileProgram() + program->source==NULL

message: fix memleak: double clRetainMemObject

message:

also use POCL_RETURN_GETINFO_STR() to return the result.

minor fixes

* add -Wall to kernel library compilation commands

required because program.bc is now linked with kernel library.

message:
Fix regression/test_locals: do not set localBuffer

Setting __local arguments is invalid by spec, one
can only set the size of __local arguments.

title: pocl llvm : Find undefined symbols in programs
message:
pocl llvm : Find undefined symbols in programs

fix clBuildProgram test, add another test for missing symbols

The test_kernel_src_in_pwd.h was calling __FUNC__ which was
only declared, this now fails due to missing symbol detection.

Do not detect undefined symbols when we're building
from sources and we already have cached build results.

Doesn't check missing symbols for TCE devices

title: Fix LLVM CPU fallback
message:
Fix LLVM CPU fallback

This makes it possible to use pocl with LLVM which doesn't
recognize your CPU, as long as you provide a sensible value
for -DLLC_HOST_CPU when you build pocl with CMake.

Also, turn a CMake warning into an error and do not fallback
to "generic" cpu if LLC can't determine the cpu model, because
"generic" cpu doesn't seem to work. Fixes #512

message: Additional checks for clSetKernelArg()

message: Add get_image_array_size prototypes

message: fix some compiler warnings

title: Fix various minor bugs in examples / tests
message:
Fix various minor bugs in examples / tests

* OpenCV fails to build because it fiddles with -I/-isystem. The
  bug has been reported to them but using -I apparently causes
  some problems (but so does using -isystem for me).
* VexCL's CMake has been updated, now it requires explicitly
  telling what to build.
* move examples/trig to internal label, so as to not confuse
  with the conformance tests.

title: CMake: tune conversion tests for short conformance testsuite
message:
CMake: tune conversion tests for short conformance testsuite

make them a bit more faster

title: Implement clUnloadCompiler()
message:
Implement clUnloadCompiler()

* add releaseLLVM() called by clUnloadCompiler(). This might (or not)
  help memory usage somewhat.
* release program->llvm_irs in clReleaseProgram()

title: cleanup pocl_llvm_api.c slightly
message:
cleanup pocl_llvm_api.c slightly

* move some of one-time initializers into InitializeLLVM()
* move the static map caches to global level so we can release them later
* add a cache of target machines (releasing them while LLVM IRs exist
  is a bad idea, not releasing them = memleaks)

message: Remove some unused code from pocl_llvm_api.cc

message:
Add a working implementation of vload_half/store_half

Uses F16C CPU extension on x86-64. Passes conformance
tests for float <-> half conversion. The vstore_half(double)
is not yet fully conformant.

title: CMake: fix pocl building on ARM architectures
message:
CMake: fix pocl building on ARM architectures

Also update README.ARM. A bunch of tests still fail, but
pocl should at least build on ARM / ARM64.

title: Fix loading of libhwloc topology
message:
Fix loading of libhwloc topology

Do not load the entire PCI tree just to read a CPU vendor
from PCI vendor ID.

title: Fix a bug in pocl_cache
message:
Fix a bug in pocl_cache

if POCL_CACHE_DIR was set but it wasn't yet created, pocl
would skip it and use XDG_CACHE_HOME/pocl/kcache.

message: Remove a few unused variables, add myself as co-author in some files

title: Do set CL_DEVICE_TYPE_DEFAULT flag on pocl devices.
message:
Do set CL_DEVICE_TYPE_DEFAULT flag on pocl devices.

Instead handle CL_DEVICE_TYPE_DEFAULT in clCreateContextFromType.
Workarounds buggy programs which assume device-type is an enum,
not a bitfield.

title: half type, vload_half() and vstore_half() are defined even if
message:

half support (cl_khr_fp16) is unavailable.

message: [CUDA] Use CloneFunctionInto to preserve attributes

message: [CUDA] Fix race on queue destruction

title: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:pocl/pocl
message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:pocl/pocl

title: Properly omit WI calls with non-const arguments.
message:
Properly omit WI calls with non-const arguments.

Fixes #509.

title: Merge branch 'cuda-cond-wait' of https://github.com/jrprice/pocl
message: Merge branch 'cuda-cond-wait' of https://github.com/jrprice/pocl

title: Added Jonas to the CREDITS.
message: Added Jonas to the CREDITS.

title: [CMake] Use LLVM_LIBDIR to construct CLANG_RESOURCE_DIR
message:
[CMake] Use LLVM_LIBDIR to construct CLANG_RESOURCE_DIR

CLANG_RESOURCE_DIR did not account for LLVM_LIBDIR_SUFFIX.
LLVM_LIBDIR is derived from llvm-config which takes care of this.

title: [CUDA] Use pthread_cond_wait in background threads
message:
[CUDA] Use pthread_cond_wait in background threads

Previously these were spin-locking which was consuming too much CPU
time.

title: Added missing (non-specs) prototypes for double.
message:
Added missing (non-specs) prototypes for double.

Fixes #507.

title: Use Clang's opencl-c.h instead of our own definitions
message:
Use Clang's opencl-c.h instead of our own definitions

Fixes #388.

title: Optimize work item function calls.
message:
Optimize work item function calls.

Merge them to a single call site in the entry to assist further
optimizations.  After inlining they (temporarily) contain loads to
pseudo variables etc. which make LLVM produce inoptimal code
in some cases.

title: Cleanups.
message: Cleanups.

title: kernel compiler: Apply standard optimations early
message:
kernel compiler: Apply standard optimations early

This prevents bloating of code before work-group
function generation which might prevent discovering
the dead / loose code later on.

It requires that the 'noduplicate' of barrier works to not
break the CFG of the single WI kernel.

Also added a few cleanups.

title: As of LLVM 5.0 we need to let CloneFunctionInfo to make module level changes,
message:
As of LLVM 5.0 we need to let CloneFunctionInfo to make module level changes,
otherwise there will be an assertion. The changes are likely
additional debug info nodes added when cloning the function into
the other.  For some reason it doesn't want to reuse the old ones.
CloneFunctionInto(NewKernel, F, VV, true, RI);

Fixes #502, #500 and #497.

title: Merge branch 'llvm-5.0-fixes' of github.com:pocl/pocl
message: Merge branch 'llvm-5.0-fixes' of github.com:pocl/pocl

title: VUA: Propagate uniform BB from switch instructions
message:
VUA: Propagate uniform BB from switch instructions

Fixes #496, #495 and #494 for LLVM 5.0 which retains the switch..case
for get_local_id() for some reason.

title: Clarify a comment.
message: Clarify a comment.

title: debughelpers: Do not overwrite previous dot dumps
message: debughelpers: Do not overwrite previous dot dumps

title: Merge branch 'next' of https://github.com/franz/pocl
message: Merge branch 'next' of https://github.com/franz/pocl

title: Fix LLVM-less build
message: Fix LLVM-less build

title: Disable inline pass for LLVM 3.9
message:
Disable inline pass for LLVM 3.9

seems to crash it for some reason, works for other versions

title: [CUDA] Handle free_ptr for clSVMFree
message: [CUDA] Handle free_ptr for clSVMFree

title: Rename CACHELINE_SIZE to HOST_CPU_CACHELINE_SIZE.
message: Rename CACHELINE_SIZE to HOST_CPU_CACHELINE_SIZE.

title: CMake: detect cacheline size.
message: CMake: detect cacheline size.

title: Refactor pocl llvm building.
message:
Refactor pocl llvm building.

The old code was holding a program write lock while
it was calling pocl_llvm_generate_wgfunc() and pocl_llvm_codegen().
Both of these could take a dozen seconds. Heavily threaded
tests were getting timeout on lock acquire.

The new code acquires LLVM IR and object file in memory, then
writes them out together.

title: Call POCL_DESTROY_OBJECT() on clRelease*
message:
Call POCL_DESTROY_OBJECT() on clRelease*

.. on objects which have pocl_lock mutex.

title: Fix SIGFPE handling
message:
Fix SIGFPE handling

block SIGFPE signal delivery in all pthread driver threads,
instead let the main pocl thread handle it.

title: pthread_scheduler: Remove an unlock() immediately followed by a lock().
message: pthread_scheduler: Remove an unlock() immediately followed by a lock().

title: Some more perf tuning.
message:
Some more perf tuning.

* In case of huge number of small workgroups, scale up
  the amount of work we fetch in get_wg_index_range()
  linearly to CU number, this helps avoiding lock
  contention in get_wg_index_range() with manycore CPUs.

title: Fix LLVM debug messages
message:
Fix LLVM debug messages

Change their category to LLVM.

title: pocl_llvm_api.cc: return to flatten-all except images
message:
pocl_llvm_api.cc: return to flatten-all except images

using flatten-globals-only for pthread driver caused serious regression,
but is necessary for image read/write to work. Scan the program
if it references image reads/writes, and only use flatten-globals
if it does, otherwise use the old way of flatten-everything.

title: remove some unused variables.
message:
remove some unused variables.

Also, make num_theads and thread_pool non-volatile
(they never change after initial setup).

title: Align some struct members & copy num_threads to per-thread storage
message:
Align some struct members & copy num_threads to per-thread storage

Aligns should help avoid false cacheline sharing.

Fetching num_threads from scheduler_data in each get_wg_index_range()
iteration is expensive, since the scheduler_data struct is shared
between all driver threads.

title: EnqueueNDRange: don't call for info we can just fetch
message: EnqueueNDRange: don't call for info we can just fetch

title: POCL_UPDATE_EVENT_* refactor
message:
POCL_UPDATE_EVENT_* refactor

remove unnecessary level of indirection
(cl_event itself is a pointer).

title: Some minor performance / scalability improvements
message:
Some minor performance / scalability improvements

* Make some structs aligned to cacheline size (to avoid false
  cacheline sharing).
* add per-thread "current_ftz" flag to store status of FTZ.
  Setting FTZ or rounding mode seems to be expensive on
  some CPUs, so we avoid it when we can.
* refactor translate_wg_index_to_3d_index() to avoid fetching
  too much data.

title: CMake: fix forgotten labels in tests/kernel
message: CMake: fix forgotten labels in tests/kernel

title: Fix another potential deadlock
message: Fix another potential deadlock

title: pthread driver: fix event locking
message:
pthread driver: fix event locking

1) when locking 2 events, always lock them in order (smaller id first)
2) always destroy & re-initialize mutexes when reusing an event

This fixes huge amount of "lock-order-inversion (potential deadlock)"
warnings from ThreadSanitizer.

Since pocl_broadcast() now calls dev>ops>notify() with event locked,
had to remove locks from all notify callbacks. Also fixed update_event()
callbacks to unlock event before calling pocl_broadcast().

title: pthread driver: do not save & restore ftz / rounding mode flags
message:
pthread driver: do not save & restore ftz / rounding mode flags

no need to do this for pthread, since it runs in its own threads.
basic driver still needs it though.

title: test_clCreateSubDevices.c: fix a bug
message:
test_clCreateSubDevices.c: fix a bug

dev_pt_size is used later for size check, so it's incorrect to turn it
into a partition type count.

title: pthread.c: replace mutex_trylock() loop with mutex_lock()
message:
pthread.c: replace mutex_trylock() loop with mutex_lock()

By itself doesn't make Pocl faster, but significantly lowers
locking overhead (the macro with pthread_trylock had a loop,
trylock in a loop is basically a spinlock).

title: basic/pthread device: report all rounding modes and FMA
message:
basic/pthread device: report all rounding modes and FMA

FMA is only reported if available (via llvm::sys::getHostCPUFeatures)

title: Fix subdevice partitioning.
message:
Fix subdevice partitioning.

For subdevices with 1 CU, ensure they're not possible
to partition further. This stops the tests from partitioning
a device recursively to infinity.

title: CMake: disable some tests that take too long on CPU devices
message: CMake: disable some tests that take too long on CPU devices

title: CMake/LLVM: update llvm-config search
message: CMake/LLVM: update llvm-config search

title: lib/kernel: Add get_image_array_size
message:
lib/kernel: Add get_image_array_size

also rename internally used get_image_array_size() to avoid
any possible confusion.

title: fix issue #486 (Release MemObject on multi-devices platform)
message:
fix issue #486 (Release MemObject on multi-devices platform)

When we create a buffer on a multi-devices platform, we do not want
any clRetainMemObject on it so that only one clReleaseMemObject is
needed to free the buffer.

title: attempt to fix -cl-ext with LLVM 4.0
message:
attempt to fix -cl-ext with LLVM 4.0

The previous code was incorrectly producing multiple -cl-ext
options, instead of a single option with +/- feature list.

title: Fix saturated conversion tests in tests/kernel.
message:
Fix saturated conversion tests in tests/kernel.

Was reporting errors like:

> FAIL: convert_int_sat_rte(float) - sample#: 7 element#: 0
> original: 2.1474836e+09 expected: 0x80000000 actual: 0x7fffffff

2.1474836e+09 after convert_int_sat should be INT_MAX not -1 (0x80000000).

title: CMake: fix (autogenerated) conversion tests in conformance testsuite.
message:
CMake: fix (autogenerated) conversion tests in conformance testsuite.

The _sat modifier may not be used for conversions to floating-point formats.
Also rounding modes for conversions between integers are meaningless.

title: convert_type: fix conversions  for {long/int}_to_{double/float}
message:
convert_type: fix conversions  for {long/int}_to_{double/float}

requires special handling toward the end of long/int ranges.

title: convert_type(): simplify source integers + destination float
message:
convert_type(): simplify source integers + destination float

In case the source integer is small enough to be exactly represented
by the destination float type, skip all the conversion tests.

title: Fix a data race in pthread_scheduler.c
message: Fix a data race in pthread_scheduler.c

title: Add stubs for unimplemented API calls (OpenGL stuff)
message: Add stubs for unimplemented API calls (OpenGL stuff)

title: Workaround a problem in pthread driver
message:
Workaround a problem in pthread driver

In some tests which use pocl with a lot of threads,
the pthread driver sometimes gets stuck in the wait loop,
waiting on empty queue.

title: LLVM 5.0: BBvectorizer is gone, remove it completely from pocl_llvm_api.cc
message: LLVM 5.0: BBvectorizer is gone, remove it completely from pocl_llvm_api.cc

title: Add a CMake option to build with thread sanitizer
message: Add a CMake option to build with thread sanitizer

title: fix alloca() with argument == zero
message: fix alloca() with argument == zero

title: Fix a memory corruption bug in pocl_build.c
message: Fix a memory corruption bug in pocl_build.c

title: Fix some compiler warnings in pocl-hsa.c
message: Fix some compiler warnings in pocl-hsa.c

title: fix saturated conversions
message:
fix saturated conversions

When calling convert_int_sat(float x) with x == (float)INT_MAX,
it's representation is rounded to INT_MAX+1,and y=convert_int(x)
sets y to 0. Subsequent select() both return y, because
(x > (float)INT_MAX) is false, and the result is 0.

This patch changes the float constants to hexadecimal literals,
and changes the condition (x > INT_MAX) to (x >= INT_MAX+1).

title: Fix flush-to-zero and default rounding mode
message:
Fix flush-to-zero and default rounding mode

For x86-64 and GCC/Clang only, set the flush-to-zero and rounding
CPU flags before each kernel run (pthread & basic devices).
Save the flag into poclbinary (changes header -> bump version).

title: basic driver: add CL_FP_DENORM to SINGLE_FP config
message:
basic driver: add CL_FP_DENORM to SINGLE_FP config

Denorms are be supported & enabled by default on x86-64 SSE/AVX

This is currently only enabled for x86_64.

title: Fix loading of poclbinaries with program.bc
message:
Fix loading of poclbinaries with program.bc

Loading program.bc at clCreateProgWithBinary()
broke a condition in build loop, this fixes the
problem and a few more issues with LLVM-less
build code.

title: Fix program.bc serializing
message:
Fix program.bc serializing

Previously the code to serialize program.bc saved it
for every kernel in the program. Move it to right after
program header (and bump pocl binary version, the change
is incompatible).

title: Fix a bug in previous PR
message: Fix a bug in previous PR

title: Fix some memory leaks
message: Fix some memory leaks

title: Fix some debug messages
message: Fix some debug messages

message: clEnqueueUnmapMemObject.c: add extra checks

message:
clEnqueueFillImage: handle 1D image buffers correctly

the previous code was creating pocl_command with the image, not the buffer.

title: clEnqueueFillImage(): remove erroneous check

title: Linux/x86: add a SIGFPE handler.
message:
Linux/x86: add a SIGFPE handler.

The OpenCL spec says:

> A divide by zero with integer types does not cause an exception
> but will result in an unspecified value.

Unfortunately x86 doesn't seem to have any flag to disable SIGFPE
from integer division by zero. To make things worse, the (I)DIV x86
instruction does not advance the IP register when the exception
is raised.

This adds a SIGFPE handler that tries to handle the situation by
decoding the instruction and skipping to the next instruction. In
case the instruction is not recognized as (I)DIV, the original
handler is invoked.

Split Flatten pass

This splits the #if-else-endif code in Flatten into two files,
Flatten and FlattenGlobal. Flatten.cc with inline-everything
(used for SPMD devices), and FlattenGlobals.cc which inlines
only functions using global variables (for pthread device).

SPMD devices (HSA) have problems compiling non-kernel inline
functions; the reason for globals-only Flatten for pthread
(CPU) device is described in commit c9d2cd1518a6f6578bb

title: pocl_topology: actually cleanup behind ourselves
message:
pocl_topology: actually cleanup behind ourselves

With 351d727ceba5f2797e932c5ad653753e21166de2 we introduced a label for
a cleanup on exit in pocl_topology_detect_device_info, however, this
wasn't actually used (erroneously).

Do jump to it if hwloc_topology_load() fails, as the hwloc documentation
suggests the topology should get destroyed anyway in this case.

Signed-off-by: Giuseppe Bilotta <giuseppe.bilotta@gmail.com>

title: lib/kernel/atomics.cl: add 64bit atomic min/max
lib/kernel/atomics.cl: fix atomic_xchg(float*, float)
message:
lib/kernel/atomics.cl: fix atomic_xchg(float*, float)

the original code wasn't casting the return value of atomic_exchange_n()
(which was int) to float, therefore float->int conversion happened,
returning nonsense.

This adds result conversion and slighty simplifies the code
by using atomic_xchg(int*, int).

title: llvm/Flatten: switch back to force-inlining only some funcs
message:
llvm/Flatten: switch back to force-inlining only some funcs

The new code in Flatten added AlwaysInline attr to everything
except kernel.

This switches Flatten back to its original code (adding AlwaysInline
only to users of global variables); additionally it adds AlwaysInline
on barrier().

The problem with flattening all code is that OpenCL spec requires
maximum number of image arguments to a kernel to be at least 127.
write_imagef() is relatively heavy on stack, and AlwaysInline on a
kernel with 127 images and 127 calls to write_imagef() will require
a giant stack, if we force inlining of all write_imagef() calls.

glibc prints the sign of NANs. Since pocl uses glibc for

changes all NANs to positive NAN before calling printf.

This patch also removes length modifiers from printf(float/half/double)
since glibc() always expects double argument.

title: LLVM trunk (r303990) fixes
message:
LLVM trunk (r303990) fixes

* New extension cl_khr_3d_image_writes supported by Clang that is
required to build some of the implementations
* Removed BarrierBlock as BasicBlock is now a 'final' class in LLVM,
thus cannot derive from it. It was pretty useless anyways.
* LLVM.cmake: the test for fake address spaces was too tight.
* Other API changes.

title: Use generic cpu when LLVM can't detect the host processor
message:
Use generic cpu when LLVM can't detect the host processor

LLVM's CPU detection is very basic, it parses /proc/cpuinfo and uses
information from their to look up CPUs in its own internal tables.
These tables are incomplete, so it's not uncommon for LLVM to not
be able to detect the CPU.

Ideally pocl would use something better than llc --version for CPU
detection, but for now we can at least fallback to the generic
cpu when LLVM can't detect the host.

title: [CUDA]: do not abort if the GPU architecture is invalid
message:
[CUDA]: do not abort if the GPU architecture is invalid

Instead, simply return an error condition.

title: pocl_cuda_init: do not abort on error
message:
pocl_cuda_init: do not abort on error

Instead, return the appropriate error condition to the caller, which
will set the device as unavailable. If we don't find the compiler
library, mark the device as missing a compiler.

Signed-off-by: Giuseppe Bilotta <giuseppe.bilotta@gmail.com>

title: Make device init return a cl_int
message:
Make device init return a cl_int

This will allow us to pass errors up through the code instead of
aborting. Presently, we simply return CL_SUCCESS in all init
device-specific init functions. pocl_init_devices() handles non-success
errors by setting the device as unavailable, with the exception of out
of memory errors that cause an early bailout, passing the error up to
the caller.

Signed-off-by: Giuseppe Bilotta <giuseppe.bilotta@gmail.com>

title: Pass per-type sequential device number to device init functions
message:
Pass per-type sequential device number to device init functions

This avoids the widespread usage of a static variable holding the
progressive number.

Signed-off-by: Giuseppe Bilotta <giuseppe.bilotta@gmail.com>

title: pocl_init_devices: handle errors more gracefully
message:
pocl_init_devices: handle errors more gracefully

Instead of aborting or asserting in case of errors during the
initialization of the device list, return an appropriate error code,
which gets passed through to the caller and thus allows the caller to
return an appropriate error code itself (which may or may not be the
same error returned by pocl_init_devices()).

Signed-off-by: Giuseppe Bilotta <giuseppe.bilotta@gmail.com>

title: [CUDA] probe and initialize all devices
message:
[CUDA] probe and initialize all devices

We ask the CUDA driver API about the number of available device. This
allows running pocl with CUDA support enabled regardless of whether CUDA
devices are available or not.

Additionally, in the initialization phase, we actually get a different
device each time rather than always the first.

Signed-off-by: Giuseppe Bilotta <giuseppe.bilotta@gmail.com>

title: get_global_id.c: Add optnone attribute
message:
get_global_id.c: Add optnone attribute

attribute optnone disables all optimizations.

This was necessary, because running opt on kernel library
introduced global "switch tables" (@switch.table.XX)
which referenced the global variables like @_global_offset*,
and this was preventing these global vars from being optimized
out after privatizeContext() in Workgroup pass. Leading to
undefined references in final .so module.

This also adds a simple pass to remove the optnone from the library
before all other kernel lib passes; it's required otherwise
some WI optimizations don't work as previously.

message:
[CUDA] Implement global offsets

Given that these aren't frequently used, we only generate a kernel
with support for global offsets if there is an enqueue with non-zero
offsets. The kernel library implementations of get_global_id and
get_global_offset have placeholder global variables for the offsets,
which are replaced with kernel arguments if offset support is
required, or constant zero otherwise.

title: Fix AutomaticLocals breaking constant expressions
message:
Fix AutomaticLocals breaking constant expressions

Replacing an automatic local with an argument doesn't work if one of the
users is a constant expressions, since function arguments aren't
constants. Instead, we first replace any constant expression users with
their equivalent instructions.

Fixes #467.

title: Fix cache locking
message:
Fix cache locking

Calling pocl_llvm_generate_workgroup_function() from clEnqueueNDrangeKernel()
was causing problems when clEnqueueNDrangeKernel() was called while the device
driver thread was already compiling something. This caused programs to either
to abort with assertion "input" missing, or lock up in pocl_acquire_lock().

- remove all direct usage of pocl_llvm_generate_workgroup_function(),
  let device->ops->compile() handle generating the parallel.bc

- make device->ops->compile() thread-safe, since it can be
  called by both device driver thread and the host program
  (from clCreateKernel or clGetProgramInfo(BINARIES...)

- remove unused kernel_cachedir argument from pocl_llvm_gen_wg,
  pocl_cache_write_kernel_parallel_bc() does its own mkdir() call.

- add a few more asserts.

title: Add categories to POCL_DEBUG messages.
message:
Add categories to POCL_DEBUG messages.

The old mechanism of running POCL_DEBUG=1 <opencl-program>, to make pocl
print a lot of debugging messages, works but is becoming unusable due to
the amount of messages produced.

This commit introduces categories and filtering by categories into debug
messages. Currently there are 9 categories:
events,cache,llvm,refcounts,locking,hsa,tce,memory,timing.

Usage:
POCL_DEBUG=memory,timing <opencl-program>

The old way (POCL_DEBUG=1) works and enables all messages.

This commit only adds the new framework, the debug messages in pocl are
left unchanged.

title: lib/CL/<images>: fix row/slice pitch & origin.
message:
lib/CL/<images>: fix row/slice pitch & origin.

1) rename row/slice pitch arguments to match signature in khronos docs

2) pocl was wrong to apply origin[] to host_ptr in clEnqRd/WrImage, because
   AFAICT it should already be adjusted -> always force origin to [0,0,0].

3) for device row/pitch we must always pass the image row/slice pitch;
   for host_ptr it's either the provided arguments or calculated from
   region[], not from image row/slice pitch.

title: clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: formatting

Revise some overlong lines and operator spacing.

title: clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: try to fill all compute units
message:
clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: try to fill all compute units

Our greedy algorithm for NULL local size may cause an imbalanced
workload, with a few compute units bearing the grunt of the work with
oversized work-groups, and the other compute units doing nothing.

We now try to achieve a better balance by further splitting the local
size so that all CUs get at least a work-group, as long as this doesn't
mean making work-groups too small.

title: clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: small robustness tweak
message:
clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: small robustness tweak

Make sure the CL_KERNEL_PREFERRED_WORK_GROUP_SIZE_MULTIPLE property was
correctly retrieved, fall back to 1 in case of failure.

title: clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: new NULL local size logic
message:
clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: new NULL local size logic

When the user does not specify a local work size, the platform should
decide one on its own.

The local size is subject to the following _hard_ constraints:

1. in each dimension, the corresponding local size must divide the
corresponding global size;
2. in each dimension, the corresponding local size must not be larger
than the corresponding device limit;
3. the overall local size (product of the local sizes in each
dimension) must not be larger than the maximum overall local size
allowed by the device.

Additionally, we would like the local size to be a multiple of the
device-recommended work-group size multiple for the kernel, to improve
device usage or vectorization opportunities. Note that this is not a
hard constraint, but rather a performance hint.

The logic previously used to determine the local size did not take into
account the hard constraints 1 and 2: it started from the global size as
potential local size and then reduced the three dimensions (by halving
or clipping) until the local size satisfies constraint 3, while trying
to satisfy the performance hint too..

This could result in an invalid local size (violating either 1 or 2
or both), which would then be caught in the subsequent checks (that
hve now been moved to the the user specified local size in the previous
commits).

This commits rewrites the logic in order to aim for correctness first,
by taking constraints 1 and 2 into account when looking for an initial
candidate for the local size. A reduction quite similar to the existing
one is then effected on the local size candidate until constraint 3 is
satisfied.

The main differences compared to the old logic are:

* to satisfy constraint 1, the grain size for the performance hint may
be a fraction of the device preferred work-group size multiple;

* in the reduction phase, we always reduce the third dimension first,
then the second dimension and finally the first one; this may result in
the new logic providing local sizes with a different shape (but the
same overall size) than the old logic, in cases where the old logic
would produce valid results.

The new logic is still not necessarily more optimal (performance-wise)
than the old logic, but is guaranteed (modulo bugs introduced by yours
truly) to produce valid local sizes, and should not introduce any
meaninful performance regressions related to overall block sizes (e.g.
concerning CU usage), but there might be shape-related performance
regressions, for kernel/device combinations where more square work-group
sizes would be preferrable.

Performance-related local size optimizations are deferred to future
patches, that may take device-specific and kernel-specific features for
local size tuning (hopefully without breaking correctness).

title: clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: do not mangle user choice of local
message:
clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: do not mangle user choice of local

The local > global case is trated (as an error) earlier on, don't
change the local size when this happens. It might make sense in the
future when non-uniform local sizes are supported though, so document
that it used to be there.

title: clEnqueueNDRange: move the local-must-divide-global check
message:
clEnqueueNDRange: move the local-must-divide-global check

Again, the requirement should be checked on the user-specified local
work size, we should never produce a lws that doesn't fit.

title: clEnqueueNDRange: move the oversized work-group check earlier
message:
clEnqueueNDRange: move the oversized work-group check earlier

We should only check that the user-specified work-group size is not too
large. We should never produce one ourselves. (Do assert if we do,
though.)

title: clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: check reqd_work_group_size compatibility
message:
clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: check reqd_work_group_size compatibility

If the kernel has a required work-group size, return
CL_INVALID_WORK_GROUP_SIZE if the user didn't specify one or specified
one that doesn't match the requirements.

title: clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: avoid a goto
message:
clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: avoid a goto

We can refactor the logic to skip the goto. While this isn't
necessarily better, it's a necessary cleanup in preparation for the
next commit that introduces the reqd_work_group_size check.

title: Workaround #439 (EinsteinToolkit hangs with LLVM 4.0)
message:
Workaround #439 (EinsteinToolkit hangs with LLVM 4.0)

The hang happens at the WG function inlining to the launcher. The
inliner's AddAliasScopeMetadata runtime explodes, likely due to
the large number of restrict kernel args in combination with a
huge number of lifetime markers. Remove the markers before
inlining to speed it up until a proper fix lands.

Fixes #439.

title: Fix printf for Clang 4.0.
message:
Fix printf for Clang 4.0.

The problem was that Clang does not allow vararg functions other that
printf in OpenCL C mode (mandated by the specs).

Fixed this by introducing only the printf declaration in .cl mode and
converting the calls at bitcode linker to the internal _cl_printf().

Also had to clean up the build a bit as it enabled OpenCL C mode even
for C builtin library files due to the OpenCL C standard switch being
passed to it.

Fixes #440.

Fixes #438.

title: Fixed a bug with the pocl binary format when using multiple kernels with the same
message:
Fixed a bug with the pocl binary format when using multiple kernels with the same

It didn't use the pocl binary in the hash at all, leading to using the
first loaded kernel which crashed because they were in reality different
and had even totally different argument lists.

Fixes #371.

title: Just declare printf directly without the macro trick for Clang 4.0.
message:
Just declare printf directly without the macro trick for Clang 4.0.

I think this should work as:
- Clang accepts it in OpenCL C mode (the only allowed vararg function)
- We compile the printf() definition in C mode.

title: Avoid the bitcode linker exploding the bitcode size
message:
Avoid the bitcode linker exploding the bitcode size

Two issues caused this (which were visible only with Clang 4.0):
- bitcast() template of pocl-compat was static which caused a copy
of the function created for each bitcode file which was finally
linked to the big one, and the copies followed. Now it's global
which should allow merging the definitions.
- There was a bug in the linker which caused it to copy functions
that were referred from multiple places multiple times by
appending the new definition to the end of the old definition.
This exploded the size of some of the helper functions
copied over.

Fixes #433.

title: clGetProgramBuildInfo binary_type information added
message:
clGetProgramBuildInfo binary_type information added

Based on OCL1.2 spec
if program will be compiled using clCompileProgram its
binary_type will be set to CL_PROGRAM_BINARY_TYPE_COMPILED_OBJECT.
clCompileProgram is currently missing in pocl!
if program was created by clLinkProgram which is called with
the –createlibrary link option its binary_type will be set to
CL_PROGRAM_BINARY_TYPE_LIBRARY.
clLinkProgram is currently missing in pocl!

title: Always optimize the builtin library bitcode.
message:
Always optimize the builtin library bitcode.

Otherwise linker.cpp takes forever and might explode the memory usage
at runtime regardless of the LLVM build type. Better pay it once at
build time. linker.cpp might also perform unneccessary copying in that
case (that should be investigated). With optimized bitcode it works
within reasonable link time and memory usage.

title: Support for building without the fake address spaces (#394)
message:
Support for building without the fake address spaces (#394)

Relies on the included patch to clang that makes it produce SPIR address
spaces in the kernel arg info metadata. It's pending review
in https://reviews.llvm.org/D26157  It applies at least to LLVM 3.9 and
LLVM trunk. Possibly also to earlier versions.

Cmake detects if the patch is applied and in that case disables the
use of fake address spaces everywhere and detects the kernel argument
address space from the metadata instead.

This will be the default in the future as soon as the patch gets applied
to LLVM upstream.

Also snuck in some misc. cleanups while going though the code.

title: TAS: do not reconstruct kernel metadata for non-SPMD devices
message:
TAS: do not reconstruct kernel metadata for non-SPMD devices

The opencl.kernel metadata needs to be maintained only for
SPMD devices (read: HSA at the time of this writing) because
for non-SPMD machines the original kernel function is not
there anymore, but is replaced with a work-group function.

The reconstruction code needs to be ported to LLVM 3.8+, but
hopefully at that point we have gotten rid of the TAS mess altogether.

title: Remove the check in WorkitemHandler that ensures the required local size
message:
Remove the check in WorkitemHandler that ensures the required local size

and the requested one match. It's a wrong place to do that check and we
can compile the WG also with 0-0-0 to produce the dynamic sized WG func.

message: Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/franz/pocl

title: Add undocumented POCL_FORCE_PARALLEL_OUTER_LOOP env.
message:
Add undocumented POCL_FORCE_PARALLEL_OUTER_LOOP env.

This env can be used to temporarily control the logic whether to attempt
injecting the parallell WI loop inside the kernel loops which has the
effect of enabling 'outer loop vectorization' across the work-items
inside the user's loops.

The default behavior is that this is not attempted in case the kernel
doesn't contain any barriers because adding the explicit barriers that
cause the outer loop vectorization also can add overheads in form of
work-item context save/restore code.

title: Add a POCL_DEBUG_LLVM_PASSES env.
message:
Add a POCL_DEBUG_LLVM_PASSES env.

* The env enables all -debug output from LLVM passes (beware, lots of
output) which is very useful when debugging/optimizing the kernel
compiler.

* Also cleaned up the pass addition code a bit and added comments.

* Removed the scalarizer option, as it doesn't seem to work very well
and LoopVectorizer is supposed to scalarize on fly. Although it doesn't
support scalarizing vector datatypes at the moment.

title: LLVM 3.9 fixes

- Clang now uses function metadata istead of module metadata for presenting OpenCL kernel info
  - Now there are two versions of "pocl_llvm_get_kernel_arg_metadata()" for llvm 3.9 and <3.9
  - SPIR examples still use module meta

- Something changed in function mangling
  - Volatile is has changed place in the mangled name
  - New svm_atomics_x86_64_llvm3_9.ll to address this issue

- Clang likes to put string literals to the constant AS
  - a bit questionable fix in kernel/printf.c

- Nice "__builtin_astype()" function for casting opaque built in types to actual implementation types

title: HSA: workaround a race condition that might lead to deadlock
message:
HSA: workaround a race condition that might lead to deadlock

If there was (another) submit after the previous wait returned, but
before this reset, we miss the notification decrement and get stuck if
there are no further submits to decrement the 1.

Currently busy waits for non-AMD until a proper fix is developed.

title: HSA: do not destroy the code objects too early.
message:
HSA: do not destroy the code objects too early.

Code objects must not be destroyed before the executables are.
We need to think of a proper spot to cleanup them as they might
be cached for future calls. There might be no safe place.

title: TCE: add an usleep() into a busy loop.
message:
TCE: add an usleep() into a busy loop.

The busy loop was eating an entire CPU core while waiting for the
result of the actual simulation running on a different core.
This drops the CPU usage of a running TCE test from 2 cores to 1 core,
at the price of adding a few milliseconds to each run.

title: CMake: try to clean up the mess that is ENABLE_ICD/DIRECT_LINKAGE
message:
CMake: try to clean up the mess that is ENABLE_ICD/DIRECT_LINKAGE

This removes DIRECT_LINKAGE option completely, and implies direct
linkage when ENABLE_ICD is false. We can't have both enabled -
direct linkage changes the POsym macro, which means the entire
runtime library would have to be rebuilt anyway.

Also cleans up lib/ and lib/CL CMakeLists of related stuff.

title: [mips] Avoid getHostCPUName(), 'generic' is not a valid -target-cpu value.
message:
[mips] Avoid getHostCPUName(), 'generic' is not a valid -target-cpu value.

The MIPS LLVM backend is not able to detect the host and returns 'generic'
this hasn't been a problem upstream but POCL feeds this value into the
-target-cpu option which rejects it. This causes almost all tests to fail.

title: TAS: fix conflict between pocl AS numbers and final AS numbers
message:
TAS: fix conflict between pocl AS numbers and final AS numbers

Some of the pocl AS numbers were the same as the final device AS numbers,
causing issues when TAS conversion code converted more than once (like
with global variables referenced later by functions). Caused problems
for both HSA and TCE.

This fixes it for both by first converting the pocl AS to high numbers,
then mapping those to actual device AS.

printf + windows). This makes the checks silent

Some of the pocl AS numbers were the same as the final device AS numbers,
causing issues when TAS conversion code converted more than once (like
with global variables referenced later by functions). Caused problems
for both HSA and TCE.

This fixes it for both by first converting the pocl AS to high numbers,
then mapping those to actual device AS.

title: Revert "reverted commit dcbcd39811638bcb953afbbfdd2620fb8ab45af4"
message:
Revert "reverted commit dcbcd39811638bcb953afbbfdd2620fb8ab45af4"

This reverts commit a74ca43706c8034fc5b5361a51f8a4d766ef66b7. Back
to the original commit.

This is causing problems with TCE, since one of the TCE AS is
numbered 4, like generic - so e.g. the global goes POCL AS -> TCE 4
then the 4 is considered generic by the following code -> AS is changed
to 0 -> fail.

title: TAS: fix generic AS on prototype arguments
message:
TAS: fix generic AS on prototype arguments

generic AS was not removed from prototypes. This was mostly not
a problem since prototypes get resolved when linked into parallel.bc,
but some (standard functions e.g. fflush() and vprintf(), mainly
called from our OpenCL printf implementation) are not resolved,
and this was causing issues with LLVM 3.8, when the actual call
has a non-generic-AS argument but the prototype still has generic AS
in argument list. LLVM would fail with error like this:

ValueEnumerator.h:132: unsigned int
llvm::ValueEnumerator::getTypeID(llvm::Type*) const:
Assertion `I != TypeMap.end() && "Type not in ValueEnumerator!"' failed.

title: CMake: add HOST_DEVICE_BUILD_HASH variable
message:
CMake: add HOST_DEVICE_BUILD_HASH variable

This is a device hash string for host CPU device.

For LLVM builds, this defaults to "{llvm triple}-{llvm cpu}".
For LLVM-less builds, is MUST be manually specified at
build time.

May be manually specified for both. They must match for LLVM-less build
to load pocl binaries produced by LLVM build.

title: kernel_library(): fallback to kernel-<triple>-<OCL_KERNEL_TARGET_CPU>.bc
message:
kernel_library(): fallback to kernel-<triple>-<OCL_KERNEL_TARGET_CPU>.bc

In theory kernel-<triple>-<runtime-detected-cpu>.bc should work, but there
are at least two cases where it doesn't:
1) running the opencl program with valgrind (valgrind changes the runtime
   detected CPU)
2) when llvm doesn't recognize the CPU (returns "unknown") and a cmake
   build is done with -DLLC_HOST_CPU=<value> hardcoded value.

message:
write_image.cl: fix argument address spaces

image2d_t are always global, so we need to cast them to global struct *

title: linker.cc: fix address space of opencl.imageX_t arguments
message:
linker.cc: fix address space of opencl.imageX_t arguments

For unknown reason (probably a bug in LLVM), llvm::CloneFunction
drops address space global from opencl.imageX_t arguments.

This adds some code in linker which reintroduces the global AS
into kernel library functions as well as user's code itself.

Having both opencl.imageX_t and dev_image_t in default AS while
having dev_image_t->data in global AS segfaults LLVM at
kernellib compilation.

title: Fix SPIR with 3.8 again
message:
Fix SPIR with 3.8 again

The original fix for 3.8 forced the module DataLayout on parallel.bc,
which turns out is problematic. This moves the code to force DataLayout
earlier (on program.bc) which seems to solve the SPIR issues.

title: TAS: handle OpenCL 2.0 generic address space with LLVM 3.8
message:
TAS: handle OpenCL 2.0 generic address space with LLVM 3.8

Note that "handle" above does not mean it's working as intended in
OpenCL 2.0 standard, this merely converts "hidden" generic pointers
(by OpenCL 2.0 standard all pointer without specified AS point to
generic AS) to pointers to private AS (the default behaviour before
OpenCL 2.0). This is enough to compile 1.2 programs with -cl-std=2.0
compile flag, but obviously does not properly handle generic AS.

Proper solution will require much more work on LLVM and pocl.

build a few variants of pocl kernel library, and then select the
appropriate at runtime depending on the CPU. Currently covers the
i386 and x86-64 archs only. To use, run CMake with
-DKERNELLIB_HOST_CPU_VARIANTS=distro

title: CMake: Build multiple host kernel libraries for different CPUs, part 1
message:
CMake: Build multiple host kernel libraries for different CPUs, part 1

This allows building the host kernel library multiple times for CPUs
selected by a CMake variable KERNELLIB_HOST_CPU_VARIANTS. The one
actually used is selected at runtime. You can see the list of
possible options by running `llc -mcpu=help`
E.g. to build for Core2 and SandyBridge CPU families, use
cmake "-DKERNELLIB_HOST_CPU_VARIANTS=core2;sandybridge"

title: CMake: fix kernel library hash computation in CMake
message:
CMake: fix kernel library hash computation in CMake

${builddir}/kernellib_hash.h contains a #define with the
SHA1 of kernel BC library, which (with other values) is used
to ensure pocl kernel cache gets refreshed when something changes.
Up until now it had contained only the SHA1 of last built library,
which worked fine when we only had one.

This commit changes that to have kernellib_hash.h include the SHA1
of *every* built kernel library, be it host, hsa, tce or other.

Changes (aside dealing with multiple kernel-<>.bc) :
 - lib/kernel was moved before lib/CL in CMake (required
   for targets' visibility)
 - kernellib_hash.cmake now only updates the
   header when the content actually changed
 - pocl_cache.c was separated into its own OBJ library, to not
   introduce a dependency on kernellib_hash.h for all of lib/CL/*.c

HSA: 2nd version of OoO driver for HSA devices, fully asynchronous

Uses a single separate pthread for actual work. Driver pthread uses
hsa_amd_signal_wait_any() or a fallback hsa_signal_wait() to wait.
Many things are not optimal, a few unimplemented, but most of the
AMD SDK samples that used to work with the old driver now pass too.

title: POCL_UPDATE_EVENT_COMPLETE(): fix a pthread deadlock
message:
POCL_UPDATE_EVENT_COMPLETE(): fix a pthread deadlock

POCL_UPDATE_EVENT_COMPLETE() locks an event then calls
pocl_update_command_queue() which tries to lock a queue
(while the event is still locked), this may deadlock with
pocl_create_command() which locks a queue first,
then its last_event.

This patch moves pocl_update_command_queue() to after event unlock.

title: struct _cl_event: add a pthread cond variable
message:
struct _cl_event: add a pthread cond variable

This is triggered only when changing event status to CL_COMPLETE

title: Disable atexit() callbacks when exiting via POCL_ABORT()
message:
Disable atexit() callbacks when exiting via POCL_ABORT()

When exiting by POCL_ABORT, atexit() callbacks are called which
try to finish the queues; but if POCL_ABORT comes from a queue,
the exiting may get stuck forever.

title: The "atomic_flag" type in C11 is a bool (which may map to char),
message:
The "atomic_flag" type in C11 is a bool (which may map to char),
but in OpenCL it is an 32bit int. That means we cannot use the
C11 builtins for operations on the OpenCL atomic_flag; this fixes it.

title: Fix local > global dim in clEnqueueNDRangeKernel()
message:
Fix local > global dim in clEnqueueNDRangeKernel()

Apparently local_work_size values must only be smaller than
CL_DEVICE_MAX_WORK_GROUP_SIZE and CL_DEVICE_MAX_WORK_ITEM_SIZES[i],
but doesn't have to me smaller than global_work_size. In that case
fallback to our local_work_size computation code.

This fixes a problem with AMD SDK sample, where it enqueues a kernel
of global sizes [1024,1,1] with local sizes [4096,1,1] (The 4096 is
CL_DEVICE_MAX_WORK_GROUP_SIZE of the CPU device).

extensions.

for int & uint; TODO find something better.

title: Some work on kernel caching / locking
message:
Some work on kernel caching / locking

The locking was a bit too eager, slowing down certain API calls.
This changes the locks so that:
1) a [program,device] write lock is acquired only when
   we need to actually write something
2) a [program,device] shared read lock is acquired at clCreateProgram*()
   This is to prevent the same program in different process to delete
   the entire program cache directory in clReleaseProgram, in case
   POCL_KERNEL_CACHE is set to zero.

title: Remove semi-colon-less macros, part 1
message:
Remove semi-colon-less macros, part 1

Prevent macros in pocl_util.h from being used without a terminating
semicolon, by removing any terminating semicolon within the macros and
wrapping them into `do { ... } while(0)` when they are composed of
multiple statements.

title: Refactor clEnqueueCopyBufferRect and clEnqueueCopyImage
message:
Refactor clEnqueueCopyBufferRect and clEnqueueCopyImage

clEnqueueCopyImage used to call clEnqueueCopyBufferRect, which couldn't
work because the latter would check that the source and destination
were actual images.

Refactor the code into a separate function, with extra parameters to
know which should be a image and which a buffer, and copy it from both
the API calls instead.

title: Implement clSetKernelExecInfo() and clSetKernelArgSVMPointer()
message:
Implement clSetKernelExecInfo() and clSetKernelArgSVMPointer()

clSetKernelExecInfo is pretty much empty for now, HSA doesn't seem
to require any action to access SVM memory indirectly.

clSetKernelArgSVMPointer creates a fake cl_mem which we pass down
as kernel arg. setup_kernel_args() in pocl-hsa.c is adjusted to
deal with the fake cl_mem.

title: Sidetrack SVMMap / Unmap in case a HSA device doesn't need any action
message:
Sidetrack SVMMap / Unmap in case a HSA device doesn't need any action

This is to avoid having to bail when SVMMap is called with blocking=true
(which isn't implemented).
If i read the  OpenCL 2.0 spec section 5.6.1 correctly, the SVMMap and Unmap
can be no-op when the SVM is fine-grained + atomics.

title: Remove custom buffer allocator.
message:
Remove custom buffer allocator.

Didn't provide much advantage over plain malloc(), it's unused and it's
complicating efforts to refactor the device memory alloc code.

title: Split pocl_set_buffer_image_limits()
message:
Split pocl_set_buffer_image_limits()

The non-image setup is now in pocl_setup_global_mem(), which sets
up a new memory-accounting struct (currently used only for the computer's
main memory).

Adds two new alloc()/free() calls, which also do memory accounting.

This commit also changes the limit of memory available to opencl
(device->global_mem_size), the previous limit was too generous - it
left no space for OS/other applications.

Now instead generate a vendor id based on a magic number.

Contexts now only keep a list of real devices internally.

title: clBuildProgram.c: Use the new subdevice macros
message:
clBuildProgram.c: Use the new subdevice macros

This (and the following commits) try to make pocl keep
internally only the "real" devices, while the runtime API
still accepts any subdevice. Command queues are an exception,
because we need the subdevice to schedule the proper # of threads.

title: pthread.c: Make pocl_pthread_run use device-max-CU-count threads
message:
pthread.c: Make pocl_pthread_run use device-max-CU-count threads

With subdevices, this number (max CU count) is no longer constant.
This commit fixes it to schedule a proper number of threads even
for subdevices.

title: pocl-cache: refactor pocl_cache_work_group_function_so_path
message:
pocl-cache: refactor pocl_cache_work_group_function_so_path

Currently pocl_llvm_generate_workgroup_function is checking
for parallel.so in cache, instead of parallel.bc. HSA does
not ever produce .so files, so this check fails and triggers
pocl_llvm_generate_workgroup_function is re-run everytime,
when using HSA.

This patch fixes the issue by changing the check to parallel.bc.

improves performance for some cases. See issue #251.

title: HSA: The program/kernel cache was wrong..
message:
HSA: The program/kernel cache was wrong..

I didn't realize that hsa_code_object_t in program cache was
being built from parallel.bc, which already only contains a single
kernel, not the entire program. This was causing issues when >1 kernel
from the same program was enqueued. This commit fixes the issue
by removing program cache and only keeping kernel cache; a better
solution would be to fix pocl_llvm_generate_workgroup_function to
generate the entire linked program.bc for HSA, but that requires
more work, hence this workaround for now.

but mainly will allow simpler overriding of native builtins in
device-specific kernel libraries (like HSAIL).

title: HSA: Add proper error handling to all HSA runtime calls.
message:
HSA: Add proper error handling to all HSA runtime calls.

Adds a new macro (HSA_CHECK) and a function pocl_hsa_abort_on_error()
which uses a new debug macro POCL_MSG_PRINT2 since the original
POCL_MSG_PRINT substitutes func/line directly, and we need to pass
them as args this time.

title: CMake: Create a new config.h only if it differs from the old config.h.
message:
CMake: Create a new config.h only if it differs from the old config.h.
This helps avoid the situation:
1) you change some CMakeLists.txt somewhere
2) you run "make" which runs cmake automagically
3) cmake rewrites config.h and the following make will pick it up
   as a change of dependency for a lot of files which #include "config.h"

   the last path element - we now have "amdgcn/" and "hsail64/" prefixes too
2) Fix a bug introduced by windows support - the list of files was written
   to a fixed-name file "kernel_linklist.txt", and since we now have multiple
   kernel.bc files, this was simply being overwritten by each func call

message:

Add the missing part of local(group) memory setup - calculating
the dynamic local memory pointers. Per comment in
https://github.com/HSAFoundation/HSA-Runtime-AMD/issues/8

The static local memory starts at base 0 and its size is <num>,
The dynamic local memory starts at offset <num>.

title: SPIR modules should not specify the target.
message:
SPIR modules should not specify the target.

The 'target triple = 'spir-unknown-unknown' tells LLVM which backend to use
but we should ignore it. The target is not SPIR when we reach the point at
which we generate target code.

Revert "Don't cast to or from (void *), especially not malloc returns"

This reverts commits 4b458c77ac6976322378cd85f96e8ff52c6b1f87 and
4c61d8734c607d98bf8c3404a2094193f4d5cbf3

The reason to revert is that, on Windows, pocl is compiled with MSVC
which only has a C++ compiler, and it's an error to NOT cast the
result of malloc in C++:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16815476/why-must-i-cast-the-result-from-malloc

Also, any modern GCC will emit an "implicit declaration" warning when
you use malloc() without including <stdlib.h> regardless of having or
not having a cast. So the only problem that remains is the clutter.

title: [cmake] Make it possible to override CL_DISABLE_HALF.
message:
[cmake] Make it possible to override CL_DISABLE_HALF.

I suspect the check is currently wrong. It seems to be checking whether C
allows half precision types in arguments and returns. On Mips, this is not
currently allowed. However, I suspect OpenCL allows this regardless of
target.

This patch removes the unconventional caching mechanism for
CL_DISABLE_HALF in favour of cmake's usual method which allows the user
to specify it with -DCL_DISABLE_HALF=ON/OFF. This allows me to investigate
whether the check is correct or not.

title: [cmake] Make it possible to specify the host CPU.
message:
[cmake] Make it possible to specify the host CPU.

Mips currently autodetects LLC_HOST_CPU="(unknown)" which is not a valid CPU
name. This had the side effect of disabling cl_khr_int64, and removing
floating point support from printf().

This patch removes the unconventional caching mechanism for LLC_HOST_CPU in
favour of cmake's usual method which allows the user to specify it with
-DLLC_HOST_CPU=...

title: Make program cachedir creation more robust
message:
Make program cachedir creation more robust

We must be able to create a cachedir even in the case of preprocessing
failure, so handle this case by hashing the original source code if no
preprocessing text is given.

Also, binaries should be invalidated whenever the hash changes, so move
the binary invalidation inside the cachedir creation function.

title: Don't OR ExecuteAction return value with previous success
message:
Don't OR ExecuteAction return value with previous success

First of all, OR-ing anything with an initially true value is
fundamentally wrong (it should be AND-ed instead). Secondly, we don't
actually need to combine the result with the previous, since we do
early checks and bail-out in case of failure before going to the next
use.

title: Sanitize pocl_create_command
Add context member to _cl_event
message:
Add context member to _cl_event

Automatic events all have an associated command queue, and this was
used to retrieve the context in clGetEventInfo. However, user events
have a NULL command queue, so this approach would lead to segmentation
faults.

Since user events still have an associated context, add the actual
context to the event structure.

title: Standard compliance for user events
message:
Standard compliance for user events

They start as CL_SUBMITTED and their status can only be set to
CL_COMPLETE or an error value.

title: Autonomous POCL_UPDATE_EVENT_* macros
message:
Autonomous POCL_UPDATE_EVENT_* macros

The macro don't need an explicit command queue passed any more, just a
pointer to an event. The command queue is taken to be the event's own
command queue, if present. The existence of the command queue is
checked before dereferencing.

(I'm not 100% sure that the check is necesary, since I _think_ the only
events that do not have an associated command queue are user events,
which shouldn't be touched by these macros, so an assert might be
sufficient.)

title: clBuildProgram: refactor token append code
message:
clBuildProgram: refactor token append code

The duplicate code to append a (valid) token to modded_options is
refactored into a macro, and the following two issues are fixed:

* a potential buffer overflow if the token length is bigger than 256 +
  whatever room is left in modded_options;
* a potential memory leak in case of reallocation failure.

title: GenerateHeader: initialize is_* arrays
message:
GenerateHeader: initialize is_* arrays

Ensure that everything is set to 0 (false) by default. It's faster,
cleaner and safer than setting variables to false later on, and avoids
potential use of uninitialized values in some corner cases.

title: clGetSupportedImageFormats: plug memory leak
message:
clGetSupportedImageFormats: plug memory leak

On a rare "out of host memory" condition, we might leak a pre-allocated
array. Free both, just in case (it's a no-op on NULL anyway).

title: clFinish: fix event deref
message:
clFinish: fix event deref

'event' is a pointer to cl_event which is always non-NULL (being
the address of a member of a struct), we want to check for the
existence of the cl_event it points to instead (before dereferencing
it).

title: pocl_llvm_codegen: avoid NULL pointer dereference
message: pocl_llvm_codegen: avoid NULL pointer dereference

title: Replace conditional checks with asserts
message:
Replace conditional checks with asserts

When allocating objects with USE_HOST_PTR flag, the host pointer _must_
be non-NULL, don't check for it in the conditional, but assert this.
Assert the condition before acting on COPY_HOST_PTR too. The conditions
(should) have been checked by the API calls first anyway.

title: clCreateSubBuffer: allocator size mismatch
message:
clCreateSubBuffer: allocator size mismatch

Found by Clang's static analyzer. We're allocating pocl_mem_identifiers,
not pointers to them.

title: clEnqueueNDRangeKernel: allocator size mismatch

title: Fix qeue => queue typo
message: Fix qeue => queue typo

title: Command queue management utility
message:
Command queue management utility

To prevent segmentation faults and other crashes when applications end,
we have to ensure that all command queue are finished before any of the
automatic destructors trigger. Otherwise, it can happen that e.g. some
LLVM globals are freed before the command queue are released, and
the subsequent release of the command queue can cause a kernel
compilation and then crash or hang inside LLVM. This is particularly
noticeable in some configuration with the ViennaCL examples.

We solve this by keeping track of all the allocated command queues and
forcing a clFinish on them at exit (which is called before the
automatic destructors).

message:

create & use preprocessed source.

Other changes:
* change the signature of pocl_llvm_build_program, add two output
  arguments which are used in clBuildProgram
* the first buildlog in pocl_llvm_build_program is saved into a buffer,
  since we don't have a cachedir yet.
* remove the usage of device->dev_id, it doesn't make sense with
  the current struct cl_program.
* move a bunch of other funcs to the new pocl_cache_*

NOTE: the device switches code (used by TCE), which depends on
an existing cachedir, remains a TODO.

title: Make the kernel cache depend on preprocessed CL source, part 4
message:
Make the kernel cache depend on preprocessed CL source, part 4

lib/CL/clBuildProgram.c: move to new pocl_cache functions. For programs
created from binaries, the pocl_cache_create_program_cachedir is moved
inside the for loop, since we don't have program->cachedir anymore.

For programs from sources, since we don't know the preprocessed
source until we're inside pocl_llvm_build_program(), we let that
function take care of creating the cachedir.

title: Make the kernel cache depend on preprocessed CL source, part 3
message:
Make the kernel cache depend on preprocessed CL source, part 3

be moved into pocl_llvm_update_binaries()

title: Make the kernel cache depend on preprocessed CL source, part 2
message:
Make the kernel cache depend on preprocessed CL source, part 2

This part changes pocl_cache functions to accept an argument "device_i"
which is an index into program->devices[].

Also:
* separate creating the cache top directory to its own function, no
  need to do it everytime we want to create a cachedir
* make pocl_cache_create_program_cachedir and build_program_compute_hash
  accept preprocessed sources
* mix in the kernel library's SHA1 into the resulting hash

title: Make the kernel cache depend on preprocessed CL source, part 1
message:
Make the kernel cache depend on preprocessed CL source, part 1

This is a series of patches to let pocl cache on SHA1 of the
preprocessed program source, instead of just program source,
which is prone to mess up caching via macros / #include etc.

This involves a rather big change in pocl caching, since it
turns out program.bc depends on device as well, so these
patches change per-program cachedirs into per-device+program
cachedirs.

Changes in this patch:
* struct _cl_program: remove cache_dir and cachedir_lock, they
  don't make sense with per-device cache dirs
* struct _cl_program: add build_hash array (for per-device SHA1)
  and build_log array (pocl_llvm_build_program might run into
  errors before it gets the preprocessed source)
* change clCreateProgram* and clReleaseProgram  accordingly

title: clBuildProgram: Do not try to reallocate program->binaries and
message:
clBuildProgram: Do not try to reallocate program->binaries and
program->llvm_irs everytime we rebuild - reallocating to smaller
arrays would lead to memleaks. Instead, walk the entire
program->devices and see which devices on the supplied list need
building.

Also, in case of clCreateProgramWithSource(), make program->binaries
(and llvm_irs) sized to its context->num_devices. Since a program
can't have more devices than its context, we won't have to realloc.

title: Change program->binaries[] to an array of separately malloc'ed
message:

pointers into it. This will allow later to re-allocate binaries
by one, as needed.

title: Clip max_work_item_sizes to max_work_group_size
message:
Clip max_work_item_sizes to max_work_group_size

CL_DEVICE_MAX_WORK_ITEM_SIZES is an array describing the maximum
number of work-items that can be indexed in a given dimension in a
work-group (not globally), so it doesn't make any sense for it to be
larger than CL_DEVICE_MAX_WORK_GROUP_SIZE, which is the overall limit
in the number of work-items in a work-group.

Just as well, since we don't have hardware work-item indices (which is
the case on GPUs instead) it also doesn't make any sense for any of the
values to be _less_ than the maximum work-group size (i.e. there's no
reason to not allow 1×1×MAX as well as MAX×1×1 and 1×MAX×1), so just
set each element of max_work_item_sizes to the value of
max_work_group_size.

Signed-off-by: Giuseppe Bilotta <giuseppe.bilotta@gmail.com>

title: Add POCL_KERNEL_CACHE_IGNORE_INCLUDES env
message:
Add POCL_KERNEL_CACHE_IGNORE_INCLUDES env

By default, the kernel compiler cache does not cache kernels that
have #include clauses. Setting this to 1 changes this so that the
includes are ignored and not scanned for changes. Use this to
improve the kernel compiler hit ratio in case you know that the
included files are not modified across runs.

title: Improvements to the implicit vectorization
message:
Improvements to the implicit vectorization

- do not unroll loops in the clBuildProgram stage to present nicer
  loops to the vectorizer (it can decide what to do with them)
- note: loopvec is the default WG method now
- print out vectorization diagnostics
- add an XFAIL test case for an issue that happens only when vectorization is
  enabled:

  at least with Intel Core i5.
- tce: fp16 test fails with loopvec, seems like a codegen issue. XFAIL for now.

title: Revamp clBuildProgram to support kernel cache feature
message:
Revamp clBuildProgram to support kernel cache feature

At the end of clBuildProgram call
1. program.bc file is generated (for both program with source & binary)
2. program->binaries are populated with program.bc contents
3. program->llvm_irs is populated by IR parsing of program.bc

since llvm_irs are always generated in clBuildProgram, dumping of
kernel.bc is avoided in further stages

TODO:
Remove references to kernel.bc. This might not be required

And the some buffers, which are allocated by "pocl_aligned_malloc", are
deallocated by "free". It makes some troubles. I also suggest all malloc
and calloc should be changed to "pocl_aligned_malloc" also "free" should
be cchanged to "pocl_aligned_free"

LLVM 3.5 is more strict with these.
