- reoder the passes so we can maintain VUA from PHIsToAllocas
- remove some dead code, cleanup some style issues

VariableUniformityAnalysis:
- in case an alloca is written from inside a diverging BB,
  the alloca is varying closes #94
- add preserve analysis for VUA in various passes to avoid losing
  the info that gets lost in PHIsToAllocas

PHIsToAllocas:
- maintain information of the split PHIs in VUA to not lose
  track of the loop induction variables after the PHI breaking

title: Make pocl more friendly with other ICD loaders than ocl-icd
message:
Make pocl more friendly with other ICD loaders than ocl-icd

- When ocl-icd is detected, tests will use it and no libOpenCL is built.
- When other ICD loader is detected, libOpenCL is built but not installed,
  and tests will use direct linkage to the built libOpenCL.
- No ICD loader means libOpenCL is built and also installed.

title: Initial CMake buildsystem commit
message:
Initial CMake buildsystem commit

Converted most of top level configure.ac and Makefile.am into CMakeLists.txt.
Added cmake versions of config.h.in, pocl.icd.in, pocl.pc.in.
Most of LLVM & Clang related stuff is in cmake/LLVM.cmake module.

Changes against configure.ac setup:
- remove install-paths.h references (most are unused anyway); replace
  PKG*DIR variables from install-paths.h with defines from config.h
- replace PACKAGE_VERSION with POCL_VERSION
- replace CLFLAGS with KERNEL_CL_FLAGS, and CLANGXX_FLAGS with
  KERNEL_CLANGXX_FLAGS - they seem more fitting and less confusing (with
  LLVM_{CXX,C,CL}FLAGS being values from llvm-config)
- changed TARGET-{LLC,CLANG}-FLAGS into {CELL,TCE}-{LLC,CLANG}-FLAGS
  seems more consistent wrt >1 ocl "targets"
- removed {TARGET,HOST}_SIZEOF_<type> defines, they all seem unused;
  there is some code using SIZEOF_<type> defines though.

Missing stuff:
- HOST_{LLC,CLANG,...}_FLAGS setup is incomplete, especially on !x86, and
  also sanitization of various triplets is missing
- Other platforms than linux need testing, may not work
- TCE & Cell need testing

remove clconfig.h.in and lib/kernel/clang.mk

Add/remove kernel functions using "half" types

OpenCL provides only a few kernel functions that take "half" types. Remove all kernel functions that we currently provide, but that are not in the standard.

LLVM crashes when half3 is used as a type. Disable shuffle with those arguments.

With these changes, I can finally run "llc kernel*.bc" without crashing LLVM.

title: Clang does not recognize __builtin_sqrt* in CGBuiltin.cpp (around line 1285)
message:
Clang does not recognize __builtin_sqrt* in CGBuiltin.cpp (around line 1285)
to be a call to sqrt and cannot selectively convert it to the llvm.sqrt.*
intrinsics with looser math flags. Therefore we have to call it as a libcall
so it regonized it. For the double we still call the __builtin_sqrt() to
disambiguate from the sqrt() to avoid infinite recursion. Probably the
correct fix is to patch CGBuiltin.cpp to recognize also the call via
__builtin_sqrt*.

title: tce: do not use --vector-backend by default.

title: tce: Disable the support for NaNs when building the kernel library to
message:
tce: Disable the support for NaNs when building the kernel library to
e.g. generate llvm.sqrt* intrinsics from sqrt() (instead of a math lib
call) which allows us to replace it with a call to sqrt HW operation selectively.

title: Implement sqrt using the sqrtf(). This enables Clang to replace it
message:
Implement sqrt using the sqrtf(). This enables Clang to replace it
with llvm.sqrt* intrinstics in case looser math flags are used to
build the builtin library.

__builtin_sqrt() is not replaced as intrinsics this way for some reason.
TODO: fix this in Clang.

title: In case of statically linking LLVM into libpocl, resolve LLVM symbols
message:
In case of statically linking LLVM into libpocl, resolve LLVM symbols
at build time.
This fixes the segfault that happened when the OpenCL application also
links in OpenGL (e.g. smallptgui), and that OpenGL is implemented with
mesa's LLVMpipe. Mesa exposes the LLVM symbols, and pocl jumped to those,
causing the error.

In standalone mode, this caused double definitions of the LLVM symbols,
so do not link LLVM libs to the llvmopencl library when in API mode, it
works fine without.

title: In 49af9a90, pocl LLVM passes were unconditionally set to compile with
message:
In 49af9a90, pocl LLVM passes were unconditionally set to compile with
-DNDEBUG. This causes kernel compile time asserts when LLVM is compiled with
assertions enabled:
llvm/lib/IR/Value.cpp:534: void llvm::ValueHandleBase::AddToExistingUseList(llvm::ValueHandleBase**): Assertion `VP.getPointer() == Next->VP.getPointer() && "Added to wrong list?"' failed.

Since llvm-config cannot be relied to pass the correct NDEBUG setting, this commit
adds a configure-time check to find out the correct value.

title: In 49af9a90, pocl LLVM passes were unconditionally set to compile with
message:
In 49af9a90, pocl LLVM passes were unconditionally set to compile with
-DNDEBUG. This causes kernel compile time asserts when LLVM is compiled with
assertions enabled:
llvm/lib/IR/Value.cpp:534: void llvm::ValueHandleBase::AddToExistingUseList(llvm::ValueHandleBase**): Assertion `VP.getPointer() == Next->VP.getPointer() && "Added to wrong list?"' failed.

Since llvm-config cannot be relied to pass the correct NDEBUG setting, this commit
adds a configure-time check to find out the correct value.

Previously _kernel.h landed in pkgincludedir instead of in
pkgdatadir/include. The rationale behind this is, that headers required
by pocl should go to pkgdatadir/include, where as headers required by
3rd parties to build against pocl go into pkgcinludedir.

assert (sizeof(long)!=8).

the BC.

title: TCE: do not use the compiled simulator as it seems to have
message:
TCE: do not use the compiled simulator as it seems to have
dynamic library loading problems. The loaded engines do not
find TCE's symbols even though libpocl.so has libtce.so link.

The dlopen chain (icd->pocl->libtce->engine) probably hides the
libtce symbols at some point. It might be fixed by recording
the libtce.so to the engine .so, but it's not trivial.

title: Add implicit barriers after the split points in case of conditional
message:
Add implicit barriers after the split points in case of conditional
barriers. This enforces non-peeled work-item loops to be generated
for the pregions generated for the conditional barriers, making
the WI loops more easily vectorizable.

Fix the pthread link error when -Werror is specified.

The ACX_PTHREAD() macro can't detect pthread properly when
-Werror is specified.  This commit fixes this issue by
removing the -Werror from $CFLAGS and $CPPFLAGS before
ACX_PTHREAD().

This commit also reverts 0ea7862e.

title: Revamp handling target triples and CPUs
message:
Revamp handling target triples and CPUs

It is necessary to specify both target triple and CPU to define the ABI. If not, e.g. x86-64 (AVX support) or ARMv6 (hardware floating-point support) break, leading to inconsistencies between the kernel library and compute kernels.

In the new approach, configure.ac defines command line options CLANG_FLAGS and LLC_FLAGS that contain all necessary flags to specify target triple and CPU. It is not necessary any more to explicitly specify a target (in fact, these are now ignored).

title: Do not use -std=c++11
message:
Do not use -std=c++11

Clang does not support all C++11 features, even when this option is
given. By default, it still usese the system's C++ library, which is
often not C++11. It is cleaner to not make any code expect that C++11
is supported.

isequal, isnan etc. need to return +1 for "true" for scalar arguments,
but -1 for "true" for vector arguments. Do this.

Introduce new templates with type signatures L_VV and L_V, where L
denotes an integer expressing a truth value (with +1 or -1 for true as
described above).

Simplify implementation and improve performance for two-argument
functions.

title: Clean up get_supported_image_formats
message:
Clean up get_supported_image_formats

When gathering information from devices, request a const ptr, since this
is what we get in return in meaningful cases (basic device). This is
more sensible anyway (we don't manipulate the devices) and removes a
compile-time warning.

While we're at it, also clarify the behavir during information gather in
the case when one device returns no supported image formats.

title: configure: check for aligned allocator in C mode
message:
configure: check for aligned allocator in C mode

The components that use pocl_aligned_malloc are all C files, so check
for availability of aligned_alloc() or posix_memalign() using the
(properly set-up) C compiler, not the C++ compiler.

This prevents compiler errors and warning raised when one of the
functions is available when compiling with C++ but not when compiling in
C (without additional flags), which is e.g. the case in the current
Debian unstable.

title: TCE needs the -ffp-contract=off when soft emulation is in use and it also leads…
message: TCE needs the -ffp-contract=off when soft emulation is in use and it also leads to huge perf degradation on x86_64 without direct HW support for fmuladd (gets converted to slow system emulation function calls). title: Use -fno-builtin to avoid clang producing extra memcpys etc. from
message:
Use -fno-builtin to avoid clang producing extra memcpys etc. from
kernel loops. Otherwise, it a) ruins wg-vectorization b) causes issues with embedded 
devices such as TCE which do not have OS and a system linker.

message:

this leads to less context data to be saved per work-item and cleaner
kernel bitcode for later optimizations

title: Fixed a performance regression with LLVM 3.3. It combined fmul+fadd
message:
Fixed a performance regression with LLVM 3.3. It combined fmul+fadd
to fmuladd intrinsics calls. These calls end up being math library calls
that cannot be inlined on processors without direct ISA support for fmuladd.
This exploded the runtime of Rodinia/CFD with a kernel that had several
calls generated and lots of work-items.

Disabled this feature by adding -fp-contract=off to clang calls in x86_64
kernel library building and the kernel builder sript.

title: Mark xfail a llvm3.3 regression on ppc.
message:
Mark xfail a llvm3.3 regression on ppc. 
Typeconversion fails when the target type is shorter than the source.
e.g.
	float f=-2;
	int i  =-2;
	(uchar)f==(uchar)i

will return false.
The float one is (internally!) 0xffffffe, the int one 0xfe.
I cannot spot the error in the generated LLVM IR, so this probably is a LLVM PPC
backend bug. But any reduced test case seems to not show this symptom.

title: Skip the the as_type test on PowerPC - it fails undeterministically with
message:
Skip the the as_type test on PowerPC - it fails undeterministically with 
corrupt data for large vector types (int/uint/float16). 
It works when pocl is built with --enable-debug, fails when built without.
As --enable-debug doesn't affect the kernel compilation (and indeed the
genereated code is the same in both cases), it seems this is an alignment
error. Further evindence towards this is that the test started to fail 
when altivec was enabled, the and the kernel uses 'lvx' instructions, that
require 16-byte aligned data.

Could not isolate the error, so I don't know if this is a pocl or LLVM bug :(

title: Merge from devel. Fully checks now with the barrier injection on.
message: Merge from devel. Fully checks now with the barrier injection on.

title: Fixed a kernel compiler bug when handling a b-loop with multiple
message:
Fixed a kernel compiler bug when handling a b-loop with multiple
latches.

The problem was threefold:

1) Detection of the need to "peel" the wiloop was faulty: post-dominance
check does not work in this case as the another branch leads always to
exit via the back edge, thus is post-dominated even though it should be
handled as a diverging region. Fixed this by counting the number of
parallel regions sharing the entry block and assuming if there are more
than one, the PR is a diverging one and should be peeled.

2) The parallel region was not found for the another latch created by
the barrier tail replication. It assumed there can be only one latch
barrier.

3) Barrier tail replication failed to replicate the latch due thinking
the PHI node values should all come from the replicated block. The
PHI node values in this case originate from the "shared" part of
the replicated diverging parallel region so there was no own copy for
the variable in the replicated part. Now it simply falls back to using
the original one in this case.

title: Fixing the regression for the fast launcher revealed a problem with the
message:
Fixing the regression for the fast launcher revealed a problem with the
byval handling in general. The byval args point to the default address
space and we assume them to be in the global. For flat address space
targets (read CPUs) this makes no difference but heterogeneous setups
fail.

Now that the fast work group launcher tries to call the kernel assuming
all args are in the global space, it crashes as it does not find a
correct finger print.

This should be fixed properly when we adopt SPIR as the input. Then the
all the args should be in pointers (to global, hopefully). 

Marked the vectorarg test as an XFAIL for now, until there's more time
to look into it.

title: Updated the CL headers and fixed a bug that happened with new cl.hpp and
message:
Updated the CL headers and fixed a bug that happened with new cl.hpp and
Khronos icd with the regression tests that used the C++ bindings.

There were multiple reasons that caused the mysterious indeterministic
crash:

- the new cl.hpp uses clRelease/RetainDevice if 1.2 support is reported
  by the device (that API was added in 1.2) our ICD dispatcher didn't
  have them listed. It also had too few elements (73 even though there are
  122 funcptrs in the dispatcher table of ocl-icd) which caused probably
  mysterious behavior when ocl_icd.h was not used to define the dispatch
  table.

- the device version string was not in correct format ("OpenCL 1.2" instead
  of "OpenCL 1.2 pocl") because it didn't return the one in the device
  driver's header. This caused the cl.hpp parser that assumed " " after the
  version number to produce undefined behavior (leading to indeterminism
  of the crash)

support is in tools/patches.

Using the Khronos loader revealed a problem with clCreateContextFromType
and ICD: the first property argument cannot be a NULL. Created a wrapper
poclu_create_any_context() and called that to create the context in the
tests that do not really care which device or platform is used (they 
really want the only platform available as restricted using
OCL_ICD_VENDORS).

title: Patch for the Khronos-distributed http://www.khronos.org/registry/cl/ ICD Loader
message:
Patch for the Khronos-distributed http://www.khronos.org/registry/cl/ ICD Loader
to make it usable for regression testing in pocl development:
- Allow overriding the .icd search path with env OCL_ICD_VENDORS (like ocl-icd does)
- Do not fail in case the directory contains non .icd files.
- Allow paths without '/' suffix.

title: Reverted the OpenCL header update for now as it opened a can of
message:
Reverted the OpenCL header update for now as it opened a can of
worms. You can merge it back by 'bzr merge -r618..617 lp:pocl'.

The C++ API implemented regression tests started to crash. The property
loading failed and it tried to free an illegal property struct in 
clGetContextWithType(). However, I'm not sure if it was because of mixed
versions (icd loader 1.1) or some actual issue revealed by the
new headers.

The ICD loader has to be updated to 1.2 so we need to warn developers 
before committing this change. E.g., clReleaseDevice() is not in 1.1
so all cl.hpp cases fail because they have a reference to it and it's
not in libOpenCL.so.

Another thing I noticed is that the regression tests link against pocl
twice and they end up depending on an installed pocl due to libpoclu
having pocl as a dependency. It should not link against it in icd mode
but to -lOpenCL. I'll fix this separately.

title: Additional changes related to fixing pass-by-value structs and vectors.
message:
Additional changes related to fixing pass-by-value structs and vectors.

- Check if host libc has C11 aligned_alloc or posix_memalign in
  configure.ac. pocl_aligned_malloc/free now use these when available.
- Added commenting to pocl_aligned_malloc/free, and pocl_size_ceil2.
- Renamed MAX_ARGUMENT_ALIGNMENT to MAX_EXTENDED_ALIGNMENT, and moved it
  into config.h, with its value detect during configuration. Updated the
  basic, cellspu, and pthread devices to use this new macro.
- Tweeked the integer-to-integer conversions with saturation to instead
  use min, max, and/or clamp instead of a relational check and select.
- Replaced deprecated SSE 4.1 assembly mneunomics in x86_64/{min,max}.cl
  as these are no longer available in newer versions of gas/llvm-as.
- Updated the test_structs_as_args regression test and confirmed that recent
  changes detecting byval arguments during kernel workgroup/metadata
  generation fix the outstanding lp:987905 bug.
- Added regression test ensuring that over-sized vectors can be passed
  by value to kernel functions.
- Marked recently exposed failing kernel tests in rewrite of
  examples/kernel/kernel.c to be expected failures for now, as these will
  likely be fixed later during additional kernel library work.
- Updated CHANGES and TODO, noting that lp:987905 is fixed plus additional
  changes since last merge to trunk.

title: Fixes problems with how pass-by-value arguments are handled during
message:
Fixes problems with how pass-by-value arguments are handled during
kernel workgroup generation.

- the GenerateHeader module pass was modified to understand byval pointer
  arguments, and treat them with the same semantics as non-pointer args.
- the Workgroup module pass was changed with codepaths to emit different
  instructions for byval pointer arguments.
- pocl_aligned_malloc/pocl_aligned_free were added to pocl_util which
  provide a portable wrapper around malloc/free or posix_memalign/free.
- pocl_size_ceil2 added to pocl_util computes the next highest power of
  two for size_t values. currently just has an portable optimized
  branchfree implementation, but it could be changed in the future to
  take advantage of __builtin_clz, or similar compiler intrinsics.
- clSetKernelArg, clEnqueueNDRangeKernel, and clFinish were changed to
  use the new pocl_aligned_malloc/pocl_aligned_free functions for
  kernel arguments.

title: Bug fix which removes extra spaces from the pthread device's extensions
message:
Bug fix which removes extra spaces from the pthread device's extensions
string. 

The OpenCL specification (section 4.2, table 4.3) describes that
extension identifiers are delimited by a single space.

This fix allows POCL to be run through the Piglit OpenGL/OpenCL test
suite, where before it would fail out due to what Piglit interpreted
as "empty" extension string identifiers.

title: Fixed bug with more recent Clang 3.3 snapshots, which has changed
message:
Fixed bug with more recent Clang 3.3 snapshots, which has changed
sampler_t to be defined as a builtin type recognized by the compiler.

Changed sampler_t to be defined only with Clang 3.2 and earlier. This
might break builds using earlier Clang 3.3 development builds.

title: * Added a new work group generation method 'loopvec' that uses wiloops without

unrolling and tries to vectorize them using the LLVM's LoopVectorizer.

* Copy the original kernel attributes to the generated work group function
to retain 'noalias' from the 'restrict' pointer qualifier etc.

title: benchmark.py can now exclude POCL kernel compiler time by retaining
message:
benchmark.py can now exclude POCL kernel compiler time by retaining
the compilation results between repeats which makes the latter
executions to reuse the old ones. 

This seems to help some of the cases which means that the AMD cases do not 
actually use the profiling queue afterall (it seems) but a gettimeofday timer 
which includes the compilation times too.

Also set POCL_BUILDING=1 when running the benchmark.py to test the pocl from the
build tree.

title: Breaks constant BitCast expressions (previously only constantGEPs) to variables…

title: Trial with LLVM 3.3(svn). It compiles now but doesn't work.
message:
Trial with LLVM 3.3(svn). It compiles now but doesn't work.

Problems encountered:
- The show stopper: 
  pocl-llvm-ld doesn't build anymore due to Module::addLibrary() being
  removed from LLVM. Maybe it's time to move to using llvm-link or
  header-only kernel library.
- image2d_t is now a opaque type detected by Clang: need to figure
  out how to convert the opencl.image2d_t of LLVM IR to our struct
  type. Disabled the image functions for 3.3 for now.
- Identical signbit.cl was duplicated under x86_64, removed it from there.
- signbit, rhadd crash Clang 3.3, most likely due to the illegal-looking
  cast. The clang fails with int3 and char3 there.

* Do not hardcode libdir on Debian (so this file is multi-arch aware)

in the -dev package)
* Remove most of superflous linkage. Several binaries and libraries are

title: Use wiloops if more than 2 work items in the WG. Do not unroll the loop by…
message: Use wiloops if more than 2 work items in the WG. Do not unroll the loop by default. Improves icache footprint and should provide a better starting point for the loop vectorizer.

title: Disabled the wg vectorization by default as it worsens the performance most of…

title: Events were not recorded in case the profiling queue was not enabled.

Events were not recorded in case the profiling queue was not enabled.

The proactive memory allocation strategy was too aggressive leading to
overflows in the allocated memory region size and thus memory allocation
failutres.

Now the MatrixMultiplication case of the AMD SDK works also in the benchmark 
mode with larger matrix inputs.

title: Make things work on OSX
message:
Make things work on OSX

Configure:
Capture, and later use TARGET

Include:
Add fix-include directory named OpenCL
Add several missing #defines for API and EXT versions
Use fix-include directory in all makefiles

Libraries:
Add PO prefix for run-time function names via a macro
Do not add PO prefix for OSX (which thus does not support ICD)

Scripts:
Hide linker warning about mis-matching architectures

title: Fix ARM build.
message:
Fix ARM build.

  this should be "the safe bet" for modern ARM platforms running Linux.
  If not run on ARMv7, it should error out at ./configure time.

* Querying of the max_wg_size attribute.

title: Use fixed address space id for all but local address space in _kernel.h.
message:
Use fixed address space id for all but local address space in _kernel.h.
This was reverted for some reason at some point. 

This is to ensure we do not lose the information of the
OpenCL address space in the Clang for targets (basically regular CPUs)
that map all them to 0. 

local is left as is because it needs special handling in Clang.
Automated local variables must be converted by it to special global
variables which are handled by pocl kernel compiler passes.

This mess will be cleaned up at latest when SPIR and its standard
address space numbers gets finished and implemented in Clang. 

This caused the issue with bfs / Parboil of not finding the atomic function 
for AS3 pointer. Now it runs successfully and is enabled in the suite.

title: Add some data collection of strided memory accesses for analysis.
message:
Add some data collection of strided memory accesses for analysis.
Reenable removal of duplicate instructions with better checking.

Split vectorization to two phases in case both memory access and arithmetic operations needs to be vectorized
1: vectorize memory operations only, using nonvectorized arithmetic to find offsets
2: drop unused instructions, like memory accesses for work items in the middle of vector
3: vectorize again the arithmetic operations
This should take care of case where vectorization of address computation prevented llvm to find offsets, as well as cases where not vectorizing work item id modifications causes inefficiency.

title: Added code to split large BBs so the dot doesn't choke on the CFG
message:

by an illegally handled PHINode in the beginning of the region.

In prod_AA of ViennaCL, Csub is created from a PHINode in the beginning of 
the region *but* it's not a loop variable/work group variable but the most 
important work item variable of the kernel. It needs to be replicated.
Somehow.

Do not context save scalar loads. They should not be work item
dependent. Unless the above issue is not fixed by replicating the 
scalarized PHI somehow like it was done at some point. Need to figure 
it out.

title: Allow to run tests when pocl is compiled in ICD mode only
message:
Allow to run tests when pocl is compiled in ICD mode only

In ICD mode only, programs must be run through the (already) installed ICD loader
(ie through the system libOpenCL.so)
Of course, this system library uses /etc/OpenCL/vendors to find available ICD, but:
- currently built POCL is not there
- putting something there require root access
- programs need to choose the correct (POCL) platform if we want to test it

ocl-icd allows to define the OCL_ICD_VENDORS environment variable
in order to change the default /etc/OpenCL/vendors directory.
So, the configure script create a specific ICD file in
$(builddir)/ocl-vendors/pocl-tests.icd
and atlocal is used to define OCL_ICD_VENDORS for tests.

So, tests can be run even when POCL is configurated in ICD mode only
at the condition that the ICD loader is ocl-icd.

Note that ocl-icd version 1.4 at least is required
(or the Debian package 1.3-3). Previous versions were buggy.

title: Include OpenCL book example support into the configure program
message:
Include OpenCL book example support into the configure program

the configure script will check for some requirements.
If all is ok, the svn checkout will be done automaticcaly

Note that now:
- the checkout is done in the sources tree (and patched here)
- but the build is done in the build tree
Makefiles and tests has been adapted to work when pocl export OpenCL symbols or not.

title: Fix linkage when libpocl does not export OpenCL symbols
message:

When POCL is configured without OpenCL symbols (ie ICD only),
programs must be linked against the (external) OpenCL ICD loader.

The configure script defines the OPENCL_LIBS and OPENCL_CFLAGS variables.
They are used in various Makefile.am instead of linking explicitly with libpocl.la

title: Merge POCL_INIT_OBJECT and POCL_INIT_ICD_OBJECT
message:
Merge POCL_INIT_OBJECT and POCL_INIT_ICD_OBJECT

Currently, all object initializations also require to set the icd field. So:
- POCL_INIT_OBJECT is renamed into POCL_INIT_OBJECT_NO_ICD
  (in case we still need it alone)
- POCL_INIT_OBJECT_NO_ICD and POCL_INIT_ICD_OBJECT are merged
  into POCL_INIT_OBJECT
- all explicit references to POCL_INIT_ICD_OBJECT are removed
  (but the one alone in clCreateSampler.c)

message: Add missing ICD field initializations

title: clCreateImage must return a value
message: clCreateImage must return a value

title: Avoid to export internal symbols
message:
Avoid to export internal symbols

This allows quicker link operations (and quicker function calls)

title: Better support for ICD build
message:
Better support for ICD build

Only one library is built (libpocl.so).
This library can provide:
* OpenCL symbol (configure option --enable-direct-linkage)
  in this case, OpenCL applications can link directly to libpocl.so
* ICD support (configure option --enable-icd)
  in this case, OpenCL applications must use an ICD loader
  [support not yet fully ready]

Important: all OpenCL function are now renamed POxxx instead of xxx
This is required as xxx symbols can be provided by an ICD Loader
  It means that all internal call to OpenCL function must use
the POxxx name instead of xxx.

message: Avoid warnings when using OpenCL 1.1 function with GCC

title: Cleanup OpenCL header files
message:
Cleanup OpenCL header files

- update headers with lastest version from Kronos site (mainly cl.hpp)
- add fix-include/ directory to fix problems in Khronos header files:
  * cl_platform.h: do not use the "deprecated" gcc attribute for
    depracated 1.0 and 1.1 OpenCL function (we use/provide them for
    compatibility)
  * cl.hpp: this is a 1.1 OpenCL C++ header that needs some fix to work
    with OpenCL 1.2 C headers
- add a --enable-install-opencl-headers configure option:
  in theory, Kronos ones should already be intalled on the system.
  By default, do not install them unless none are found on the system.

title: [build] use pkg-config to find hwloc
message:
[build] use pkg-config to find hwloc

(and no need of version-info: this is only a libtool convenience library)

title: [build] llvm-ld must be build before examples
message:
[build] llvm-ld must be build before examples

some examples such as examples/standalone/ use llvm-ld

title: Improve clGetPlatformInfo
message:
Improve clGetPlatformInfo

* fix reported OpenCL Version
  From Khronos doc:
    OpenCL version string. Returns the OpenCL version supported by the
    implementation. This version string has the following format:
    OpenCL<space><major_version.minor_version><space><platform-specific information>
* all supported extensions should declared here so that programs can
  found them through an ICD Loader (ie installed headers files on the
  system will be the ones from Khronos, not the one provided by Pocl
  when multiple OCL ICD are available)
* use POCL as suffix extension. Pocl does not provide private
  extensions (yet), but we can declare a raisonable extension suffix
  (ie POCL)

title: FIX: WorkitemLoops: Context save code for a PHINode was inserted immediately
message:
FIX: WorkitemLoops: Context save code for a PHINode was inserted immediately 
after the PHINode even if there were more PHINodes after that, thus breaking 
the assumption that all PHINodes are in the beginning of the BB.

title: A major (thinko) fix. The peeled iteration of course should be
message:
A major (thinko) fix. The peeled iteration of course should be
skipped only in the very first iteration in case there are more
than one dimensions. Now it skips it using a function local 
variable which stores the initial value for the x-dim loop.
Most of the !long cases work.

title: Disable cleanup after vectorization.
message:
Disable cleanup after vectorization.

Reenable test.
Should fix bug #1039055

message: Updated requered chain length back to 2.

title: Add missing metatada copying in case of shufflevectors used to replace outputs.
message: Add missing metatada copying in case of shufflevectors used to replace outputs.

title: Reorganize creation of metadata. Less magic numbers to pick from, easier to see…
message:
Reorganize creation of metadata. Less magic numbers to pick from, easier to see from bitcode which instructions are from same or different work item and if they are from same or different line.
Remove some unused options.
Add option to disable vectorization of arithmetics with 'poison' values - those are typically computations of work item indeces and tend to break vectorization of loads and stores due to inability of scalar evaluation to pass through vectorized computations.
Import from llvm svn caching of pointer ofset information before fusing the instructions.

title: FIX: get_global_offset() was not recognized correctly due to the wrong
message:

title: Do not add the loops in case the WG size == 1. This fixes a crash
message:
Do not add the loops in case the WG size == 1. This fixes a crash
that appeared in the test_bitset case when optimizing the replica.
Might be a hidden bug or some optimization just figures the code
is never executed.

title: Fixed a bug where id initialization code was added to
message:

a wrong place causing an infinite loop. Now all regression 
tests pass with the WILoops.

title: Two bugs fixed from the WILoops:
message:
Two bugs fixed from the WILoops:

- context arrays for temporary variables without names got
  name clashes, fixed by generating a temp name using a
  running number
- in case a region entry BB had multiple PHI nodes, only the
  first one was broken down to allocas, now the whole BB is
  iterated so the first PHI removal doesn't stop the iteration

Two new regression test cases now pass.

title: Use new[]/delete[] and vector<> instead of dynamic local arrays

The run() device driver hook now takes the whole command node object

title: Cleanup the kernel compiler temp directory in clReleaseProgram.

This can be disabled by 'export POCL_LEAVE_TEMP_DIRS=1'.

of C++ global objects which might still use the directories in
their destructors which are called in atexit() in an undefined
order.

Call clReleaseProgram from clReleaseKernel because kernels
retain the program at creation.

message:

the cld of Rodinia enough to be added to the test suite (still takes
a minute or two though).

title: Mem objects are now retained in clEnqueue(NDRangeKernel,Read,Write,Copy) and
message:
Mem objects are now retained in clEnqueue(NDRangeKernel,Read,Write,Copy) and
released in clFinish(). The ViennaCL tests still work so I assume the leak/crash is

title: The case (marked as XFAIL) 21: for-loop with computation after the brexit
message:
The case (marked as XFAIL) 21: for-loop with computation after the brexit 
now replicates a kernel crash occuring in ViennaCL's examples/tutorial/fft.

An issue revealed by this case was that it traversed a back edge in this
case, replicating too much in the BTR due to faulty loop backedge
detection. Replaced it with a dominance-based check that fixed it. Anyways,
the actual crash is not directly caused by this but it's caused by the
fact that the replicated tail is the exit part of the inner loop, jumping
to the outer loop's header, thus creating a new edge to the loop header.
This requires the phi nodes to be fixed to account for the new variable
alternatives.

title: Always inline all non-kernel functions in Flatten, regardless if
message:
Always inline all non-kernel functions in Flatten, regardless if
they use the magic variables or not.

Drop uncalled functions (including kernels we are not generating a WG for) 
by calling globaldce. This results also in not processing the kernels we
are not interested by the latter passes in the WG generation. Should speed up 
kernel compilation and code generation, reduce "noise" when debugging and
reduce the final binary size.

title: IsolateRegions now adds a dummy node to the beginning of Regions that
message:
IsolateRegions now adds a dummy node to the beginning of Regions that 
start with a barrier  to enforce better replication of Regions. This fixes 
a problematic ViennaCL case.

IsolateRegions is now ran just before workitem replication aswell to
"normalize" regions touched by the CanonicalizeBarriers, LoopBarriers and
BarrierTailReplication.

title: Initial work with ICD.
message:
Initial work with ICD.
The following issues remain:
-Order of functions in the dispatch is unkown, now alphabetical.
 Khronos ICD sample code is the definitive reference, but it is
 available only for Khronos members.
 see: http://www.khronos.org/registry/cl/extensions/khr/cl_khr_icd.txt
-The contents of the dispatch get linked when ICD loads the pocl library.
 This results in the pocl dispatch struct pointing to the ICD loader wrapper
 functions, not the pocl implementations. This might also be a strange bug.
-All ICD objects (POCL_ICD_OBJECT) but platform have their dispatch uninitia-
 lized.
-configure needs a --with/--without-icd option optionally disable icd

message: Avoid (technically) undefined operation

title: Proposal for a binary format that can store the final compilation results.
message: Proposal for a binary format that can store the final compilation results.

title: Made the exit and entry BBs explicit in the ParallelRegion data
message:
Made the exit and entry BBs explicit in the ParallelRegion data
structure. The problem was that the construction of PR got a set
of BBs as input an it assumed the first and the last were the
entry and the exit, respectively. Of course this is not always the
case due to set ordering. It also assumed the Function order of
the BBs was always such that the entry node got as the first BB and
the exit node as the last BB.

title: Further bugs fixed while testing ViennaCL:
message:
Further bugs fixed while testing ViennaCL:

* Tail replication replicated some blocks multiple times in case
  the replicated tail contained branches. This lead to unreachable
  blocks hanging around the place and crashing some succeeding pass.

* Inline the functions before starting the rest of the handling. This
  fixes the case where there are barriers in subfunctions called by
  the kernel, such was the case with vector-test of ViennaCL. That
  no longer crashes in the kernel compiler, but with:

  pthread.c:562: pocl_pthread_run: Assertion `d->current_dlhandle != ((void *)0)' failed.

  Need to resolve this.

* PHI nodes were not reference fixed after BTR thus the test case produced
  the undominated variable usage error. Fixed this by handling also the PHI
  nodes (needs special treatment as the operand does not dominate it by 
  definition).

* Some ViennaCL tests seem to run now, at least blas3 started to execute
  but it's quite slow as it seems to compile a lot of kernels.

title: Fix for LLVM 3.0 compilation from Heikki Kultala.
message:
Fix for LLVM 3.0 compilation from Heikki Kultala.

Fixed a bug revealed when running the checks with LLVM 3.0: the unnamed
variables were not renamed nor book kept correctly which lead to broken
undominated references as the reference fixer couldn't handle them. 

Now all unnamed variables are named with .pocl_temp.#  names. 

make check passes with LLVM 3.0 now.

title: Fixed a too hasty copy-paste.
message: Fixed a too hasty copy-paste.

title: Check for libltdl.
message: Check for libltdl.

title: Updated the passes in the standalone script.
message: Updated the passes in the standalone script.

title: Merge from trunk
message: Merge from trunk

title: Fixes the case when there was a split BB with a barrier in the
message:
Fixes the case when there was a split BB with a barrier in the
header that jumped to exit. The case was incorrectly split. It
should be replicated as a whole. Added a pass IsolateRegions which
adds dummy nodes to SESE Region exit blocks that ensures the
BTR does not mess this type of cases up.

Another bug was fixed in BTR. The replicated block variable references
were not updated correctly, only the uses were, thus local variables
were corrupted.

title: Fixed an issue when replicating a conditional barrier region
message:
Fixed an issue when replicating a conditional barrier region 
multiple times. It might happen that the chaining was attempted
to the "Unreachable" block that has been left there to mark the
impossible path (according to barrier semantics). In that case,
the code now tries the block before that in the region which should
be the correct if-branch.

The variable reference fixing now checks for more indices than the
first pocl_1 one as there might be many in this type of replications.

title: Fixes the case of tail replication before WI ID dependent code.
message:
Fixes the case of tail replication before WI ID dependent code.
It's not correct to always add a barrier to the split block because
the condition can be ID dependent. 

Reverted back to the old behavior of conditional barrier replication and
fixed a bug that appeared with that: when a BB is duplicated multiple
times, like happens with conditional barriers the variables defined
in the BB are updated to the reference map only once, thus overwriting
the old clone's variables. This causes some users to use the wrong
variables (not dominated). I fixed this by appending a prefix to the
multiply cloned BBs and fix the undominated references by trying the
alternative. Currently the kludgish (but quite fast) way is to just
try with and without the added .pocl_1 suffix, in case the instruction
has an operand that doesn't dominate it.

title: (XFAIL) regression test for #940549.
message: (XFAIL) regression test for #940549.

title: Adds the barrier to the preds of both tails as there can be
message:
Adds the barrier to the preds of both tails as there can be
more entries to the exit than two.

In case GH created a new kernel function after processing the locals,
delete the old one so it won't hang in the module as an unnamed function.

message:

message:

message:

title: Another attempt for fixing #938123. The problem wasn't in
message:
Another attempt for fixing #938123. The problem wasn't in
replicating the code but replicating the variables. The inner
loop referred to an outside-loop gid which wasn't corrected
to the replicated value because that region wasn't handled yet.

Fixed it to first produce the ParallelRegions so it finds all
variables after which to start replication.

Another issue was with the loop with volatile iteration variable which
created a construct that allowed the loop be skipped entirely (i = 0;
check; loop;). There was a barrier missing from the loop skip check
which caused multiple replication to happen which exploded the thing.

There's one XFAIL still in ./testsuite -k regression

title: There was an issue with kernels that had two or more ParallelRegions where
message:
There was an issue with kernels that had two or more ParallelRegions where
the latter was a block with phi nodes (basically a for-loop which uses
private variables). The problem was due to the phi-nodes getting broken
in replication. This case is now a regression test 'barrier-between-for-loops'.

Originally, the for-loop formed a ParallelRegion with the first
basic block being the single BB loop that branched to itself. 
However, the barrier node is not part of the ParallelRegion as it should 
not be replicated. Therefore, it was not added to the reference map system 
which is used to correct references in instructions to point to the cloned
basic blocks.

This resulted in a replicated ParallelRegion with a phi node that referred
to the original "entry BB", not the correct one (the preceeding barrier
BB). The fix for this was to always create a (dummy or not) basic block
after the barrier blocks. These blocks become part of the ParallelRegion,
thus get replicated and reference fixed normally, leading the for-loop
getting the phi nodes corrected.

Search CanonicalizeBarriers for "ENTERS_A_BLOCK_WITH_PHIS" for the
location where the barrier containing BB is split.

title: Use size_t for _local_id&co. This removes a zext in address
message:

TCE. Need to figure it out from the target we are compiling for.

title: Several bugs fixed in the Region Allocator.
message:
Several bugs fixed in the Region Allocator.

The regions are now attached to the device data. The device data
and the regions is freed when a context containing the device is freed.
This produces reuse of Regions across multiple kernel calls to minimize
buffer malloc calls.

via --disable-region-allocator.
